text.wiki:
Lausanne (, also US: , French: [lozan], German: [loˈzan]; Arpitan: Losena [lɔˈzəna] (listen); Italian: Losanna; Romansh: Losanna) is the capital city and biggest town of the canton of Vaud in Romandy, Switzerland. A municipality, it is situated on the shores of Lake Léman (French: Le/Lac Léman). It faces the French town of Évian-les-Bains, with the Jura Mountains to its north-west. Lausanne is located 62 kilometres (38.5 miles) northeast of Geneva.
The municipality Lausanne has a population of about 140,000, making it the fourth largest city in Switzerland, with the entire agglomeration area having about 420,000 inhabitants (as of January 2019). The metropolitan area of Lausanne-Geneva (including Vevey-Montreux, Yverdon-les-Bains, and foreign parts) was over 1.2 million inhabitants in 2000.Lausanne is a focus of international sport, hosting the International Olympic Committee (which has recognized the city as the "Olympic Capital" since 1994), the Court of Arbitration for Sport and some 55 international sport associations. It lies in a noted wine-growing region. The city has a 28-station metro system, making it the smallest city in the world to have a rapid transit system. Lausanne hosted the 2020 Winter Youth Olympics.


== History ==
The Romans built a military camp, which they called Lousanna, at the site of a Celtic settlement, near the lake where Vidy and Ouchy are situated; on the hill above was a fort called Lausodunon or Lousodunon (The "-y" suffix is common to many place names of Roman origin in the region (e.g.) Prilly, Pully, Lutry, etc.). By the 2nd century AD, it was known as vikanor[um] Lousonnensium and in 280 as lacu Lausonio. By 400, it was civitas Lausanna, and in 990 it was mentioned as Losanna.

After the fall of the Roman Empire, insecurity forced the residents of Lausanne to move to its current centre, a hilly site that was easier to defend. The city which emerged from the camp was ruled by the Dukes of Savoy and the Bishop of Lausanne. Then it came under Bern from 1536 to 1798, and a number of its cultural treasures, including the hanging tapestries in the Cathedral, were permanently removed. Lausanne has made repeated requests to recover them.
After the revocation of the Edict of Nantes in 1685, Lausanne became (along with Geneva) a place of refuge for French Huguenots. In 1729, a seminary was opened by Antoine Court and Benjamin Duplan. By 1750, 90 pastors had been sent back to France to work clandestinely; this number would rise to 400. Official persecution ended in 1787; a faculty of Protestant theology was established at Montauban in 1808, and the Lausanne seminary was finally closed on 18 April 1812. During the Napoleonic Wars, the city's status changed. In 1803, it became the capital of a newly formed Swiss canton, Vaud, under which it joined the Swiss Federation.


=== Modern history and heritage ===

In 1964, the city played host to the Swiss National Exhibition, displaying its newly found confidence to play host to major international events.
From the 1950s to 1970s, a large number of Italians, Spaniards and Portuguese immigrated to Lausanne, settling mostly in the industrial district of Renens and transforming the local diet.
The city has served as a refuge for European artists. While under the care of a psychiatrist at Lausanne, T. S. Eliot composed most of his 1922 poem The Waste Land ("by the waters of Leman I sat down and wept"). Ernest Hemingway also visited from Paris with his wife during the 1920s, to holiday. In fact, many creative people – such as historian Edward Gibbon and Romantic era poets Shelley and Byron — have "sojourned, lived, and worked in Lausanne or nearby".The city has been traditionally quiet, but in the late 1960s and early 1970s, a series of demonstrations took place that exposed tensions between young people and the police. In the early 1980s, the Lôzane Bouge protests demanded the city "open an autonomous centre, lower cinema ticket prices, liberalise cannabis and end the process of keeping records on homosexuals, all accompanied by leaflets, chants, and songs in the street". Protests occurred in 2003, against the G8 meetings.


== Geography ==


=== Topography ===

The most important geographical feature of the area surrounding Lausanne is Lake Geneva (Lac Léman in French). Lausanne is built on the southern slope of the Swiss plateau, with a difference in elevation of about 500 metres (1,640 ft) between the lakeshore at Ouchy and its northern edge bordering Le Mont-sur-Lausanne and Épalinges. Lausanne boasts a dramatic panorama over the lake and the Alps.
In addition to its generally southward-sloping layout, the centre of the city is the site of an ancient river, the Flon, which has been covered since the 19th century. The former river forms a gorge running through the middle of the city south of the old city centre, generally following the course of the present Rue Centrale, with several bridges crossing the depression to connect the adjacent neighbourhoods. Due to the considerable differences in elevation, visitors should make a note as to which plane of elevation they are on and where they want to go, otherwise they will find themselves tens of metres below or above the street which they are trying to negotiate. The name Flon is also used for the metro station located in the gorge.
The municipality includes the villages of Vidy, Cour, Ouchy, Mornex, Chailly, La Sallaz, Vennes, Montblesson, Vers-chez-les-Blanc, Montheron and Chalet-à-Gobet (871 m (2,858 ft)) as well as the exclave of Vernand.
Lausanne is located at the limit between the extensive wine-growing regions of Lavaux (to the east) and la Côte (to the west).
Lausanne has an area, as of 2009, of 41.38–41.33 square kilometers (15.98–15.96 sq mi) (depending on calculation method). Of this area, 6.64 km2 (2.56 sq mi) or 16.0% is used for agricultural purposes, while 16.18 km2 (6.25 sq mi) or 39.1% is forested. Of the rest of the land, 18.45 km2 (7.12 sq mi) or 44.6% is settled (buildings or roads), 0.05 km2 (12 acres) or 0.1% is either rivers or lakes and 0.01 km2 (2.5 acres) or 0.0% is unproductive land.Of the built-up area, industrial buildings made up 1.6% of the total area while housing and buildings made up 21.6% and transportation infrastructure made up 12.5%. Power and water infrastructure as well as other special developed areas made up 1.4% of the area while parks, green belts and sports fields made up 7.5%. Out of the forested land, all of the forested land area is covered with heavy forests. Of the agricultural land, 11.1% is used for growing crops and 4.2% is pastures. All the water in the municipality is in lakes.The municipality was part of the old Lausanne District until it was dissolved on 31 August 2006, and it became the capital of the new district of Lausanne.


=== Climate ===
Lausanne has an average of 119.7 days of rain or snow per year and on average receives 1,153 mm (45.4 in) of precipitation. The wettest month is May during which time Lausanne receives an average of 117 mm (4.6 in) of rain. During this month there is precipitation for an average of 12.1 days. The driest month of the year is February with an average of 67 mm (2.6 in) of precipitation over 8.8 days.
The USDA Hardiness Zone for Lausanne-Pully is 8b with an average minimum temperature of −7.0 C over the past 20 years (1997–2016), but at the lake level, it can be considered 9a.

		
		
		


== Politics ==


=== Coat of arms ===
The blazon of the municipal coat of arms is Gules, chief argent.


=== Administrative divisions ===
The city is divided into 18 quartiers, or districts, sometimes composed of several neighborhoods. They are: Centre (1), Maupas/Valency (2), Sébeillon/Malley (3), Montoie/Bourdonnette (4), Montriond/Cour (5), Sous-Gare/Ouchy (6), Montchoisi (7), Florimont/Chissiez (8), Mousquines/Bellevue (9), Vallon/Béthusy (10), Chailly/Rovéréaz (11), Sallaz/Vennes/Séchaud (12), Sauvabelin (13), Borde/Bellevaux (14), Vinet/Pontaise (15), Bossons/Blécherette (16), Beaulieu/Grey/Boisy (17), and Les Zones foraines (90)


=== Government ===
The municipality (la Municipalité) constitutes the executive government of the City of Lausanne and operates as a collegiate authority. It is composed of seven councilors (French: conseiller municipal/conseillère municipale), each presiding over a directorate. One of the members act as mayor (syndic). In the mandate period 2016–2021 (la législature) the Municipality is presided by Monsieur le Syndic Grégoire Junod. Directoral tasks, coordination measures and implementation of laws decreed by the Communal Council are carried by the Municipality. The regular election of the Municipality by any inhabitant valid to vote is held every five years. Any resident of Lausanne allowed to vote can be elected as a member of the Municipality. Since 14 April 2003, due to the constitution by canton of Vaud not only Swiss citizen have the right to vote and elect and being elected on communal level, but also foreigners with a residence permit of at least 10 years in Switzerland and 3 years in the canton of Vaud. The current mandate period is from 1 July 2016 to 30 June 2021. The delegates are elected by means of a system of Majorz. The mayor is later on elected as such by a public election as well by a system of Majorz, while the heads of the other departments are assigned by the collegiate. The executive body holds its meetings in the Town Hall (L'Hôtel de Ville), in the old city on Place de la Palud.As of 2016, Lausanne's Municipality is made up of three representatives of the PS (Social Democratic Party, of whom one is also the mayor), and two members of PES (Green Party), and one each of le Parti Ouvrier et Populaire Vaudois (POP) & gauche en mouvement (an alliance of the left parties POP (Parti Suisse du Travail – Parti Ouvrier et Populaire) and solidaritéS and indépendant.e.s), and PLR (Les Libéraux-Radicaux (PLR)), giving the left parties a very strong six out of seven seats. The last election was held on 28 February/20 March 2016. The mayor was elected by two ballots on 17 April/8 May 2016.

Simon Affolter is Town Chancellor (chancelier municipal) since for the Municipality.


=== Parliament ===

The Communal Council (Conseil communal) holds legislative power. It is made up of 100 members, with elections held every five years. The Communal Council decrees regulations and by-laws that are executed by the Municipality and the administration. The sessions of the Communal Council are public. Unlike members of the Municipality, members of the Communal Council are not politicians by profession, and they are paid a fee based on their attendance. Any resident of Lausanne allowed to vote can be elected as a member of the Communal Council. Since 14 April 2003, due to the constitution by canton of Vaud not only Swiss citizen have the right to vote and elect and being elected on communal level, but also foreigners with a residence permit of at least 10 years in Switzerland and 3 years in the canton of Vaud. The Parliament holds its meetings in the Town Hall (Hôtel de Ville), in the old city on Place de la Palud.The last election of the Communal Council was held on 28 February 2016 for the mandate period (la législature) from 1 June 2016 to 31 May 2021. Currently the Communal Council consist of 33 members of the Social Democratic Party (PS), 21 Les Libéraux-Radicaux (PLR), 17 Green Party (PES), 12 Swiss People's Party (UDC), 11 Ensemble à Gauche (an alliance of the left parties POP (Parti Suisse du Travail – Parti Ouvrier et Populaire) and solidaritéS and indépendant.e.s), and 6 Le Centre (an alliance of Christian Democratic People's Party (PDC) and Green Liberal Party (pvl)).


=== Elections ===


==== National Council ====
In the 2019 federal election for the Swiss National Council the most popular party was the Green Party which received 27.3% (+11.4) of the vote. The next five most popular parties were the PS (26.7%, -4.2), PLR (15.1%, -3.6), the UDC (9.3%, -6), the POP/solidaritéS (9%, +1.9), the pvl (6.9%, +3.4). In the federal election a total of 26,070 votes were cast, and the voter turnout was 39.7%.In the 2015 federal election for the Swiss National Council the most popular party was the PS which received 30.8% of the vote. The next three most popular parties were the PLR (18.7%), the Green Party (15.9%), and the UDC (15.4%). In the federal election, a total of 26,116 voters were cast, and the voter turnout was 41.0%.

== Demographics ==


=== Population ===
Lausanne has a population (as of December 2018) of 139,111. As of 2013, 42% of the population were resident foreign nationals. Over the last 10 years (1999–2009) the population has changed at a rate of 9.9%. It has changed at a rate of 8.3% due to migration and at a rate of 2.6% due to births and deaths. The population of the greater Lausanne area (grand Lausanne) is 402,900 (as of December 2014).Of the population in the municipality, 58% or 80,828 have a Swiss citizenship, while 16,908 or 12.1% are from Lausanne and still lived there in December 2013. There were 27,653 or 19.8% who are from somewhere else in the same canton, while 36,276 or 26.0% have a Swiss citizenship in another canton. 58,9562 or 42.0% have a foreign citizenship.In 2000, most of the population spoke French (98,424 or 78.8%), with German being second most common (5,365 or 4.3%) and Italian being third (4,976 or 4.0%). There were 62 people who speak Romansh.In 2008 there were 840 live births to Swiss citizens and 623 births to non-Swiss citizens, and in same time span there were 862 deaths of Swiss citizens and 127 non-Swiss citizen deaths. Ignoring immigration and emigration, the population of Swiss citizens decreased by 22 while the foreign population increased by 496. There were 9 Swiss men and 57 Swiss women who emigrated from Switzerland. At the same time, there were 2230 non-Swiss men and 1802 non-Swiss women who immigrated from another country to Switzerland. The total Swiss population change in 2008 (from all sources, including moves across municipal borders) was an increase of 883 and the non-Swiss population increased by 2221 people. This represents a population growth rate of 2.6%.The age distribution, as of 2009, in Lausanne is; 11,818 children or 9.4% of the population are between 0 and 9 years old and 12,128 teenagers or 9.7% are between 10 and 19. Of the adult population, 21,101 people or 16.8% of the population are between 20 and 29 years old. 22,158 people or 17.6% are between 30 and 39, 18,016 people or 14.4% are between 40 and 49, and 13,940 people or 11.1% are between 50 and 59. The senior population distribution is 11,041 people or 8.8% of the population are between 60 and 69 years old, 8,277 people or 6.6% are between 70 and 79, there are 5,896 people or 4.7% who are between 80 and 89, and there are 1,171 people or 0.9% who are 90 and older.

As of 2000, there were 58,100 people who were single and never married in the municipality. There were 48,990 married individuals, 7,797 widows or widowers and 10,027 individuals who are divorced.As of 2000 the average number of residents per living room was 0.64 which is about equal to the cantonal average of 0.61 per room. In this case, a room is defined as space of a housing unit of at least 4 m2 (43.1 sq ft) as normal bedrooms, dining rooms, living rooms, kitchens and habitable cellars and attics. About 6.5% of the total households were owner occupied, or in other words did not pay rent (though they may have a mortgage or a rent-to-own agreement).

As of 2000, there were 62,258 private households in the municipality, and an average of 1.9 persons per household. There were 31,205 households that consist of only one person and 2,184 households with five or more people. Out of a total of 63,833 households that answered this question, 48.9% were households made up of just one person and there were 306 adults who lived with their parents. Of the rest of the households, there are 13,131 married couples without children and 11,603 married couples with children. There were 3,883 single parents with a child or children. There were 2,130 households that were made up of unrelated people, and 1,575 households that were made up of some sort of institution or another collective housing.In 2000 there were 1,833 single family homes (or 23.1% of the total) out of a total of 7,925 inhabited buildings. There were 3,634 multi-family buildings (45.9%), along with 1,955 multi-purpose buildings that were mostly used for housing (24.7%) and 503 other use buildings (commercial or industrial) that also had some housing (6.3%). Of the single family homes 324 were built before 1919, while 153 were built between 1990 and 2000. The greatest number of single family homes (498) were built between 1919 and 1945. The most multi-family homes (933) were built before 1919 and the next most (906) were built between 1919 and 1945. There were 180 multi-family houses built between 1996 and 2000.In 2000 there were 69,383 apartments in the municipality. The most common apartment size was 3 rooms of which there were 22,408. There were 9,579 single room apartments and 7,388 apartments with five or more rooms. Of these apartments, a total of 61,056 apartments (88.0% of the total) were permanently occupied, while 6,840 apartments (9.9%) were seasonally occupied and 1,487 apartments (2.1%) were empty. As of 2009, the construction rate of new housing units was 2.1 new units per 1000 residents.As of 2003 the average price to rent an average apartment in Lausanne was 1064.08 Swiss francs (CHF) per month (US$850, £480, €680 approx. exchange rate from 2003). The average rate for a one-room apartment was 597.46 CHF (US$480, £270, €380), a two-room apartment was about 792.33 CHF (US$630, £360, €510), a three-room apartment was about 1044.64 CHF (US$840, £470, €670) and a six or more room apartment cost an average of 2024.55 CHF (US$1620, £910, €1300). The average apartment price in Lausanne was 95.3% of the national average of 1116 CHF. The vacancy rate for the municipality, in 2010, was 0.17%.

=== Religion ===
From the Reformation in the 16th century, the city was mostly Protestant until the late 20th century, when it received substantial immigration, particularly from largely Catholic countries. Catholics now form a plurality of the city's population.
From the 2000 census, 47,225 people (37.8% of the population) were Roman Catholic, while 33,993 (27.2%) belonged to the Swiss Reformed Church. Of the rest of the population, there were 2,698 members of an Orthodox church (2.16%), there were 65 individuals (0.05%) who belonged to the Christian Catholic Church, and there were 4,437 individuals (3.55%) who belonged to another Christian church. There were 849 individuals (0.68%) who were Jewish, and 7,501 (6.00%) who were Muslim. There were 452 individuals who were Buddhist, 772 individuals who were Hindu and 343 individuals who belonged to another church. 21,080 (16.88%) belonged to no church, were agnostic or atheist, and 7,590 individuals (6.08%) did not answer the question.


=== Crime ===

In 2014 the crime rate, of crimes listed in the Swiss Criminal Code, in Lausanne was 167.3 per thousand residents. During the same period, the rate of drug crimes was 49.5 per thousand residents, and the rate of violations of immigration, visa and work permit laws was 21 per thousand residents.


== Transport ==

Lausanne is served by an extensive network of local, national and international public transport. National and international passenger trains of the Swiss Federal Railways depart from Lausanne railway station, which is also the hub of the Réseau Express Vaudois commuter rail system, and a stop on the city's metro. The metro and local buses are operated by Transports publics de la région lausannoise (TL), with many routes run using trolleybuses. Additional commuter trains are run by the Lausanne–Echallens–Bercher railway (LEB) from Lausanne-Flon station. Ships across Lake Geneva are provided by the Compagnie Générale de Navigation sur le lac Léman (CGN).
Lausanne became the first city in Switzerland to have a rubber-tyred metro system, with the m2 Line which opened in October 2008. The rolling stock is a shorter version of the one used on Paris Métro Line 14. Further expansion of the system is planned, as is the re-introduction of trams.Lausanne is connected to the A1 motorway on its west side (Geneva – Zürich axis) and to the A9 on its north and east side (for transit with Italy and France); the interchange between these two motorways is on the north-west side of the city.
Lausanne Airport is located at Blécherette, and also houses a Boeing 737 Simulator. The city is also directly linked by train to the Geneva International Airport, four times an hour, in 42min.


== Economy ==

As of  2010, Lausanne had an unemployment rate of 8%. As of 2008, there were 114 people employed in the primary economic sector and about 25 businesses involved in this sector. 6,348 people were employed in the secondary sector and there were 698 businesses in this sector. 83,157 people were employed in the tertiary sector, with 6,501 businesses in this sector.There were 59,599 residents of the municipality who were employed in some capacity, of which females made up 47.4% of the workforce. In 2008 the total number of full-time equivalent jobs was 75,041. The number of jobs in the primary sector was 93, of which 56 were in agriculture, 34 were in forestry or lumber production and 3 were in fishing or fisheries. The number of jobs in the secondary sector was 6,057 of which 1,515 or (25.0%) were in manufacturing, 24 or (0.4%) were in mining and 3,721 (61.4%) were in construction. The number of jobs in the tertiary sector was 68,891. In the tertiary sector; 8,520 or 12.4% were in wholesale or retail sales or the repair of motor vehicles, 2,955 or 4.3% were in the movement and storage of goods, 4,345 or 6.3% were in a hotel or restaurant, 4,671 or 6.8% were in the information industry, 6,729 or 9.8% were the insurance or financial industry, 8,213 or 11.9% were technical professionals or scientists, 5,756 or 8.4% were in education and 14,312 or 20.8% were in health care.In 2000, there were 55,789 workers who commuted into the municipality and 19,082 workers who commuted away. The municipality is a net importer of workers, with about 2.9 workers entering the municipality for every one leaving. About 1.9% of the workforce coming into Lausanne are coming from outside Switzerland, while 0.1% of the locals commute out of Switzerland for work. Of the working population, 40.9% used public transportation to get to work, and 35.1% used a private car.
Philip Morris International, a tobacco company, has its international headquarters in Lausanne.
Tetra Laval, a multinational packaging corporation, has its international headquarters in Lausanne.
Nespresso, an operating unit of the Nestlé Group, based in Lausanne.
Logitech, the computer peripherals company has its headquarters in Lausanne.


== Education ==

In Lausanne about 40,118 or (32.1%) of the population have completed non-mandatory upper secondary education, and 22,934 or (18.4%) have completed additional higher education (either university or a Fachhochschule). Of the 22,934 who completed tertiary schooling, 38.7% were Swiss men, 31.3% were Swiss women, 17.1% were non-Swiss men and 12.9% were non-Swiss women.In the 2009/2010 school year there were a total of 12,244 students in the Lausanne school district. In the Vaud cantonal school system, two years of non-obligatory pre-school are provided by the political districts. During the school year, the political district provided pre-school care for a total of 2,648 children of which 1,947 children (73.5%) received subsidized pre-school care. The canton's primary school program requires students to attend for four years. There were 6,601 students in the municipal primary school program. The obligatory lower secondary school program lasts for six years and there were 5,244 students in those schools. There were also 399 students who were home schooled or attended another non-traditional school.Lausanne is home to a number of museums including; the Collection de l'art brut, the Espace Arlaud, the Fondation de l'Hermitage, the Musée cantonal d'archéologie et d'histoire, the Musée cantonal de géologie, the Musée cantonal de zoologie, the Cantonal Museum of Fine Arts, the Museum of Contemporary Design and Applied Arts, the Musée de l'Élysée and the Musée historique de Lausanne. In 2009 the Collection de l'art brut was visited by 27,028 visitors (the average in previous years was 33,356). The Espace Arlaud was visited by 9,222 visitors (the average in previous years was 14,206). The Fondation de l'Hermitage was visited by 89,175 visitors (the average in previous years was 74,839). The Musée cantonal d'archéologie et d'histoire was visited by 14,841 visitors (the average in previous years was 15,775). The Musée cantonal de zoologie was visited by 30,794 visitors (the average in previous years was 30,392). The Musée cantonal de géologie was visited by 28,299 visitors (the average in previous years was 24,248). The Cantonal Museum of Fine Arts was visited by 26,456 visitors (the average in previous years was 26,384). The Museum of Contemporary Design and Applied Arts was visited by 28,554 visitors (the average in previous years was 22,879). The Musée de l'Élysée was visited by 36,775 visitors (the average in previous years was 37,757). The Musée historique de Lausanne was visited by 23,116 visitors (the average in previous years was 22,851).As of 2000, there were 12,147 students in Lausanne who came from another municipality, while 2,258 residents attended schools outside the municipality.


=== Libraries ===
Lausanne is home to eight large libraries or collections of libraries. These libraries include: Cantonal and University Library of Lausanne, the library of the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Lausanne (EPFL), the libraries of the Réseau EPFL, the Bibliothèque municipale de Lausanne, the Haute école de travail social et de la santé (EESP), the HECV Santé, the Haute école de la santé La Source and the École cantonale d'art de Lausanne (ECAL). There was a combined total (as of 2008) of 3,496,260 books or other media in the libraries, and in the same year a total of 1,650,534 items were loaned out.

== Culture and arts ==


=== Heritage sites of national significance ===
There are 46 buildings or sites that are listed as Swiss heritage site of national significance. Additionally, the entire old city of Lausanne and the Vernand-Dessus region are listed in the Inventory of Swiss Heritage Sites.
Religious Buildings: Notre-Dame Cathedral, Swiss Reformed Church of Saint-François, Swiss Reformed Church of Saint-Laurent and the Synagogue at Avenue de Florimont.
Civic Structures: Former Hôpital at Rue Mercerie 24, Former Federal Tribunal, the Former Académie at Rue Cité-Devant 7, Casino de Montbenon, St-Maire Castle, Bois-de-Vaux Cemetery, Fondation de l’Hermitage and House de maître, Railway station, Beau-Rivage Palace, City Hall, Hôtel des Postes, Administration Building of André & Cie. S.A., Administration Building of the Vaudoise Assurances, Apartment and Office Building at Rue du Grand-Chêne 8, Les Bains de Bellerive, l’Estérel House, House at Chemin de Chandolin 4, the Mon-Repos estate at Parc de Mon-Repos, Olympic Museum and Archives of the International Olympic Committee, the vessels of the CGN (La Suisse (1910), Savoie (1914), Simplon (1920), Rhône (1927)), Pont Chauderon, the Vernand-Dessus rural site, Site de l’Expo 64 avec Théatre de Vidy, the Tour Bel-Air and the University Hospital of Lausanne (CHUV).
Museums and Libraries: Former Residence of the Bishop of Lausanne which is now the Lausanne Museum of History, Bibliothèque des cèdres (former Bibliothèque des pasteurs), Beaulieu Castle and the Collection de l'art brut, Fondation Toms Pauli Collection de tapisseries and d’art textile, Galeries Saint-François, Musée de l'Élysée, Museum of Contemporary Design and Applied Arts (MUDAC), Cantonal Botanical Museum and Gardens, the Roman Museum, the Palais de Rumine with the Musée cantonal de géologie, Cantonal Museum of Zoology, Cantonal Museum of Fine Arts, Musée monétaire cantonal de Lausanne (Cabinet des médailles) and Musée cantonal d'archéologie et d'histoire.
Archives: Archives of the Banque Vaudoise, Archives of the City of Lausanne, Archives of Énergie Ouest Suisse (EOS), the Radio Suisse Romande archives and the Federal Supreme Court of Switzerland with archives.
Archeological sites: The Roman era/medieval hill-top city and the prehistoric settlement and Roman era Vicus of Vidy (Lousanna).
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		


=== Culture ===

The Orchestre de chambre de Lausanne, the Lausanne Opera and the Ensemble vocal de Lausanne provide a diverse and rich musical life. The latter has been under the direction of Michel Corboz for many years.
In January, the Prix de Lausanne, a famous dance competition, takes place at the Palais de Beaulieu (the biggest theatre in Switzerland) over a one-week period. The event attracts dancers and some of the big names in dance from all over the world.
The Swiss Film Archive is based in Lausanne and the city hosts film festivals such as the Festival cinémas d'Afrique and the Lausanne Underground Film and Music Festival. In addition to modern cinemas, the "Capitole" (in activity since 1929) is the biggest cinema in Switzerland (currently 867 seats).The town hosted the Eurovision Song Contest 1989. Each July, the Festival de la cité is held in the old part of town. Other music festivals include the Bach Festival, the Festival et concours Bach de Lausanne, which follows the Nuit de musées (museums' night) in the fall season.
Lausanne is also the home of the Béjart Ballet.

== Sports ==

Lausanne is home to the IOC, with water sports available on the nearby lake and mountaineering in the nearby mountains. Cycling is also a common pastime, with the vineyards in the surrounding hills providing extensive views and challenging routes. There is an annual Track and field meeting (Athletissima), road running through the city (the 20 km (12 mi) of Lausanne), the Tour de Romandie road cycling race, Marathon of Lausanne and triathlon competition, among other sports events. The two most important sports are ice hockey and football. Lausanne will host the 2020 Winter Youth Olympics and the 2020 IIHF World Championship.

text.quote: Towering 1100s Gothic cathedral, known for its ornate painted portal, belfry & vibrant rose window.
trip: This is a beautiful cathedral. Very majestic from the outside and well maintained inside. The organ and stained glass were the highlight for me.
The most beautiful site in Lausanne for me, combining the architecture of two different styles, the majesty and the mistery. The organ is a must see and must hear.

Inside, we paid to go up in the bell tower. Went up, looked at the large bells and then continued up to higher levels and more bells. I would definitely suggest that you walk up those old time-worn stone steps and have a look around.
Beautiful spot to stop and find peace in the city. The Rose Window is so beautiful. There are quite a few stained glass windows telling various stories if you have time to stop and peruse them.
The cathedral is quite amazing with a standout organ. Interesting history highlighting the reformation. Wonderful photography exhibit as well.

For those who are fond of churches & cathedrals, from the architecture point of view and of course for a moment of meditation and prayer. This Cathedral is a great example and a must when in. Lausanne
It’s a nice cathedral but rather surprisingly small. I enjoyed browsing and the pretty stained glass windows. If in the area, as I was, stop in.
The cathedral is very nice, but not that large. The stained glass windows are beautiful. We planned to return another day to climb the tower, but never had the opportunity.
It's a quite nice visit, nevertheless, if you have been to a number of cathedrals in other cities you won't find this one worth visiting as it's not really stunning inside.

And inside the church itself is quite small for how large the structure is. If you're in the city, you'll probably take a look, but it'll be quick. A bit of a view from the benches out front, but it's probably better from the top of the cathedral's tower (I did not climb it). It
This is a nice cathedral with long history. But if you have been to a number of cathedrals in other cities, you may not have a strong feeling from it.
It was an okay cathedral. I really went to climb the tower and get the views from the top. Well worth the climb. Even better when you can get the senioir rate!

We took the challenging walk all the way from lakeside to the Cathedrale du Lausanne, and were quite impressed. A quick tour inside reveals the magnificent church organ, and then we climbed the 242 steps to the top of the tower, which reveals some wonderful views of Lausanne &

We love visiting the great cathedrals, such as Rouen and Chartres, and so didn't expect all that much in Lausanne. But it was a lovely cathedral with a surprisingly interesting exhibit in the tower. The tower is absolutely worth climbing, for a spectacular view across the city

Although it's a typical example of cathedrals of the time, the climb to the top of the tower was worth it for great views and especially watching the bell ringing (have ear-plugs - rolled-up tissues worked).

This cathedral is without question the most impressive, beautiful and worshipful space in Lausanne, rising above the city in majestic splendor, Its very location makes it a bit of a challenge to get there, but the effort is rewarded. There is virtually no parking nearby.
A haul up to the top part of Lausanne but use the excellent metro, then enjoy fabulous views from the cathedral, plus coffee and ice cream in one of the cafes just down a little.
Walked from the train station (up hill) but worth it after seeing the views outside the cathedral. Visually lovely, calm place

Looked very impressive from the Lausanne flon bridge but it is not that impressive from Inside. Actually there is so much houses around it is hard to get a good view. There is a nice sitting area of in front of the church that one point might have offered good view of the lake
Great to visit in Lausanne. The views from the cathedral area are amazing and the cathedral is beautiful. The walks to get there are great! A must see in Lausanne

After our tour of the Parc de Mon Repos, we hiked our way uphill to the cathedral; it is quite the workout the way we came as it was all uphill and we had to take a couple breathers before we made it to the top by the cathedral. The cathedral was dedicated in 1275 and is
The cathedral is very beautiful, but it's a normal cathedral from 13th century. Compared to the French ones, it's not that remarkable...

One of the iconic landmark of the ciy. If you are in Laussane even for a day or few hours, take a quick stroll to the cathedral, it involves a litlle uphilll climb but the good thing is that you go through the old city which is very refreshing with cobblestone road, market and

Yesterday I had the pleasure of visiting the Lausanne Cathedral. This was a fabulous example of 12 Century Gothic architecture. From the amazing artistic and architectural details on the outside you walk through the doors to find even more of the same. Everywhere you looked was

Love the Gothic architecture , the history and the fact that one can go all the way to the top of the cathedral and have this amazing view of Lake Geneva and the city below. You're in Lausanne....you have to visit and go up to the top....it's defintely worth the 5francs...just

Easy to access via train, don't pay the extra amount for a tour from the city centre. Great view, slow water fountain. There's a co-op nearby so if you want to have a get some drinks or picnic this is a nice place

This beautiful cathedral, located high above Lausanne, has great views of Lake Geneva and the portions of Lausanne that lie below. It dominates the area of Lausanne called Old Town. There are a number of stairs to climb to reach Old Town from New Town.

This is a beautiful church that goes back to the 12th century and is quite didn't from many other churches I've visited. The Gothic facades, paints on the walls, the drawings on the rose stained windows are all distinctly different from other churches we've visited that belonged

We visited the 12th century Gothic cathedral in the afternoon just in time for a group tour. The lovely lady generally conducts tours in French but she gladly took us in her group and with the consent of the other tourists, conducted the tour in English. Tours are about 45 min

The Bell Tower has three different viewing platforms. The first level is reached by an easy to walk wooden staircase followed by a very wide stone spiral staircase. After walking around the wide platform look for a open door in one of the four corners; inside is a typical
Nice church though at my age, I need to labor with the numerous steps. My teenage daughter has no problem with the stairs. Worthy of time and labor.
At the Top of the Hill Of the Old Town Stands a Beautiful Cathedral. Majestic and an Amazing View Of Lausanne.

This cathedral is literally the highest point in Lausanne. It is a beautiful spot without a doubt. We walked up a 500-year-old wooden staircase to get there and the views were amazing. You can climb to the top of the church spire if you want although we opted not to do that.
We enjoyed the stained glass, the statues, the beautiful arches. A nice area to walk around and explore also.

We spent a day in Lausanne and wandered into this cathedrale. There is really not much to see. And it is not in good repair. Much of the beauty that might have once been in this church was striped out during the reformation. Very stark.

If walking to the cathedral, be prepared to climb. Hard to decide between climbing the steps or walking the steep incline at the final approach. We chose the steps. The stonework around the entrance and the stained glass windows inside impressed me most. There are also lovely
Very impressive entrance with a lot of carving, beautiful stain glass windows, very high gothic arch, the cathedral is beautiful if you have time please go and visit.
It was free to walk through this cathedral. It was very nice, with nice stained glass. We happened to be there when they played a little concert on the organ. Very cool sound.
The cathedral is beautiful especially the rose shaped stain glass window. The paintings inside are also very remarkable.

Very nice Gothic cathedral with an amazing view at the top of the tower. On the way up there was a level with the old choir stalls and a small exhibit. Most of the stairs were quite manageable; it got narrower and steeper almost at the top. The reward is a wonderful view of
Nice piece of architect, walk by, and sightseeing. Placed in a nice location but not more than a couple of mins thing to see

Top of the city. Directly on the metro line. Very easy to access. There was an organist playing the beautiful organ in the church. We climbed the bell tower. Well worth the climb to see the city, the lake and the mountains. Weather was perfect

Wonderful 12th century gothic cathedral. Originally a Roman Catholic cathedral, but was taken over by protestants during the early 1500's. While in the cathedral you must see the rose window and the original entrance. Both provided biblical education to those early worshipers

We had to climb I don't know how many stairs to reach the cathedral from the metro, but it was well worth it! A beautiful building with remarkable stained glass windows. I wish we could have been there for one of the organ recitals they have.
Free entry to a lovely building. Beautiful stained glass windows and vaulted roof. An interesting display about their statues with text in English, French and German. Certainly worth a visit.

When you are in Lausanne, visiting the cathedral is a great option. It is a gothic cathedral built in the 12th century. It is not as impressive as some French cathedrals, but definitely beautiful. An nice bonus point is the amazing view over the city of Lausanne and the Alps.

As reformation came to Lausanne like many other churches with rich decorations also this church was stripped away from many of its decorations, but still in its simplicity the cathedral is beautiful inside and, if you have time for a quided tour, I am sure you get better insight
A beautiful cathedral in the city center which is worth taking time to visit. The stained glass windows and organ are pretty amazing.
beautiful but lacking some of the ornateness that you see from the grand old buildings. it will shine again as it looks like it is being renovated/restored/ good views from the top./
We visited on Good Friday in time for the morning service. What a stunning building in the middle of Lausanne
Great historical experience very informative although there was no tour available. However sufficient information is available in text form. Beautiful place.
If you are visiting Lausanne, make sure to climb up to the cathedral! Best view over the city! And yes its a little climb up=) the city is not flat as you will figure out

Inconspicuous from outside but splended inside. Rebuild in Lens limestone between 1892 and 1909 on the foundations of an original dating from the early 16th century. Tower of Belfry is open for a visit, you will get ther from shop and information part. In the middle of the
wandered up to the cathedral on my first afternoon and enjoyed both walking around the outside and spending time inside - such a beautiful place full of history and yet so calm. worth a visit

Lausanne’s religious history is rich and complicated. This beautiful Cathedral has withstood the test of time and bears testament to Lausanne’s long and fascinating history. The stained glass windows, particularly the rose, are very beautiful and are definitely worth a visit!

The cathedral is in Lauranne's Old Town which is up a very steep hill from the main station. However, apart from the work out the climb will give you, it's worth it as you get great views of around Lausanne from the nearby terrace and the cathedral itself is an impressive gothic
Nice. Visit if you have time. In the summer tends to be overcrowded. Bear it in mind when you plan your visit.

A beautiful Gothic temple with a long history. Very well preserved, the stained glass and statues are amazing and it offers a breathtaking view of the city from the bell tower. Don't miss it while visiting Lausanne!
A beautiful architectural masterpiece with an amazing interior and if you are lucky enough during a sunny day you can witness an amazing view of Lausanne and Lac Leman from the rooftop.
Very big cathedral and abit of a trek to get to it. However the views from the top are amazing and give a real glimpse of the city. Didn’t get a chance to go in as it was just reaching closing time
Weather permitting, a beautiful, high altitude view of the heart of Lausanne and of its lake. Worth the trip and the photos.

Entry into the building is free and breathtaking! If you are in Geneva do not miss this place! If you want to climb up to the tower, entry fee for adults in 5chf but be prepared to Climb a lot of steep stairs. Once up top however, it is worth every moment!
Huge and magnificent! Piece of art and the best landmark in Lausanne. You can miss it. No guide available

Cathedrale is the most important religious building located in Lausanne, a city in Switzerland. It is located in the upper part of the old town, so you can see it from some places in the city. The building was built in the Middle Ages and now it is a Protestant Cathedral.

Once you've climbed the hundreds of stairs the Cathedral welcomes you like no other, it sits proudly above the city of Lausanne commanding amazing views. Walk through the massive double doors and the Cathedral opens up before your eyes in all its glory, it really is a lovely

I was able to drive up the hill all the way and park right in front of the church's door steps, that was on December 25th, not sure how it would be any other day. It took over a century of construction work before the Protestant Notre-Dame Cathedral of Lausanne was consecrated
It's very beautiful and worth visiting there. From there we get a view of the whole city and the lake and mountains! Very nice indeed.

While in Lausanne, make sure to visit the Cathedrale de Lausanne! Beautiful stained glass windows, a church organ with more than 7000 pipes, wooden benches and statues - I like such places. And... the most adorable thing is that you can pay 5 euros and get to the top of the

The cathedral is one of the most famous places to visit in Lausanne. We enjoyed the steps and walk up to the cathedral more than the church itself. Unfortunately, we were not able to appreciate the beauty of the cathedral as wooden benches and structures were built in the

It is a must-visit place in Lausanne. The cathedral is a very beautiful building, not so interesting on the inside (as it is a typical, austere, catholic cathedral with not many things to see) as on the outside. But what makes the visit really worthy is the breathtaking view of
I was a very happy that we have decided to climb up all the way to the cathedral and discover Lausanne, the beautiful works of art and the view from the place.
A very nice cathedral worth visiting . On the highest part of Lausanne with very nice view . Very nice music instrument .

This is a Notre Dame church.....and for anyone who likes the architecture in Churches it is a must visit, if for one or the other reason you are in Lausanne. The carvings in rock all around are as good as anywhere else in the world. Some of the medieval paint on the walls still

Easily accessible. Great views of the Lake and city from the terrace. Lovely stained glass windows and Rose window. High ceilings with Vaulted arches. Plain Calvinist interiors. Magnificent church organ.

It sits fairly high on the upgrade of the city. Waking up to get there will give you a good workout. Then the steps to the top ensure you won't need a trip to the gym😀. All worth it though. The views are fantastic. Even got to see a choir practicing on the main level of the

A Cathedral with a beautiful design. Definitely had a bit of work done on it because the arch around the door looks brand new while the rest of the front looks aged in comparison. Inside is vast with a stunning organ and altar at the front. It’s a bit of a climb from the main
It is an impressive Gothic church which is dedicated to Notre-Dame.There is a very rich collection of vitreaux and a huge musical instrument.

I really enjoyed my visit to this lovely gothic cathedral. The rose window, the splendid gates, tje intricate archtecture. A good place to sit down for some introspection. Put on your headfones and listen to J.S. Bach or Faure's requiem, or better yet: go to one of the live

The cathedral is an excellent example of Gothic architecture. The inside is vast and the design is worth the trek up the hill. However, what lacks is the design that was originally in the church before the Reformation. Moreover, remaining objects before the Reformation are
very big and beautiful cathedral. were at the cathedral at 17:45 it was closed. walked around. beautiful view of the city. three viewing platforms.

What a beautiful place to visit. The mixed reviews suggested that this wasn't a good place by some but we were very impressed with it. I would recommend that you pay to go up the bell tower and look out at Lausanne from the very top - an excellent view. It is free to get in.

Well worth a visit! Finding this beautiful cathedral was our highlight in Lausanne, the views over the city and out toward the lake are really nice. What we liked most about this cathedral was the detail which has gone into the building, from around the central doorway to

This is the crown jewel of the walking tour of Lausanne and well worth a few extra climbing steps to visit. We enjoyed the stunning architecture, statues, stained glass, organ and grand feel of the Cathedral. It was not our favorite European cathedral but very impressive none

Yes, it is protestant, and calvinist at that, so, no, there is not much extra adornment as that was removed during the rather stern Swiss reformation led by Calvin, a very good friend of John Knox. But my goodness what a beautiful building! And because there are no adornments,

There is a pretty steep climb form the Metro to get to the summit on which the cathedral sits, but given that the historical museum is right beside it, it is worth the effort. For aficionados, it is a classic, well preserved, early Gothic building with several attractive

A glorious cathedral in Lausanne, in the midst of historical buildings and parks. Hearing the bells chime the hour is quite awesome. When you walk inside the cathedral, you are in awe of it's majesty! A must see, when in Lausanne!

Lausanne is extremely hilly, so the easiest way to reach the Cathedral and the Old Town is by using the Metro subway. The Visitor's Information is located right next to the Metro and they were most helpful in telling us which stop to exit for the Cathedral. The Cathedral

Every cathedral that you enter has something different to offer. Beautiful artwork and stained glass. The organ is impressive to view. A nice stop while visiting Lausanne. Nice view from the small plaza outside of the front door.
I thought I had seen the most interesting cathedrals in Europe, but this building is a nice surprise as an example of pure early gothic style.

I was staying in Geneva and decided to take a side trip to Lausanne. Of a few attractions there the cathedral was on top of my list. I didn't regret this decision. Magnificent! Two museums worth checking out across the street, too. A few cozy cafes and bars. Nice view of the

Must visit if you are in the area. Incredible piece of architecture with beautiful stained glass windows. If you have the chance to listen to the organ playing you will get the filling that you are in another world, this place has an incredible acoustic. Even the hike from the

Stunning architecture and stained glass that has been very well renovated (and looks like parts are still being renovated). This is my favorite Cathedral next to Notre Dame in Paris, worth seeing if you are in the area.
If you are interested in church architecture or history I’m sure you would enjoy this visit. We were not very knowledgable so quick tour for us.

Free to enter (unless you want to go up the tower), the cathedral is a beautiful, peaceful space. Some of the stained glass windows were absolutely beautiful and I enjoyed spending time looking at them. Definitely worth a visit if you have time in Lausanne.
The cathedral s stairs is famous. After reach the top, the reward is beautiful viewing platform and museum. It’s all worth.

One of the most interesting aspects of the Cathedral is the various panels that give information about the figures engraved around the main doorway. However the building itself is also a stunning location to spend some time.
Wonderfully restored cathedral. Take the metro PAST the cathedral and walk down. Walk back down through the steps back to town, passing beautiful old store fronts and interesting cafes.

The history here is interesting, but it’s still an active church. I would expect the church to demand respect from visitor. There are signs posted to be quiet and to not take flash photography. But there were tour guides shouting to their customers, flashes constantly and swarms
Highest Vortex in town! Feel the vibes! The energy! The prana! The Sacred Geometry! The love! The sharing! The portal! Be the next in line!

I loved walking around this old Gothic cathedral and exploring all the detail work for a while. I especially liked the statues carved into the columns; they had that Middle Ages style of representing people, and I could even see the remnants of red and blue paint that may have

...and for a good reason. After an initial life as a catholic sacred building, it became protestant and never got the luxurious decoration and priceless art that its catholic brethren received. On top of this, in a purely Swiss way, quality of construction is paramount, so
The cathedral is located overlooking the city and worth the steep hike. The cathedral is peaceful and serene

You can easily reach the top of Lausanne. There is a Nice wiew to the city, and as well you can visit the Cathedral for free, it is beautiful inside and outside too! If you like Nice places, buildings, then highly recommend to visit the Cathedral area!
Beautiful views amazing cathedral, walking distance to shops and cafes. Well worth a visit must go and see.
Nice Entrance and stain. Glassed windows. The Alter was nice with some good paintings. But not really my thing

The only Protestant cathedral outside England taft I have visited and the 1st Gothic ( flying buttresses) built outside France . 5 Francs for access to the top of the bell tower- great views. Stained glass is sometimes contemporary but looks very impressive especially the

This cathedral was originally Catholic before eventually becoming Protestant. It has been distinguished by both periods and would appear fancy for a Calvinist, but not very expressive for a catholic. There is nothing exceptional that would justify a trip, but if you are in

Wonderful, quiet, large cathedral that has windows that survived much of the Protestant Reformation wanton destruction of stained glass windows and other art works that once graced the insides of Europe's great cathedrals.
Walking around Lausanne we came across this cathedral. In one word, stunning. Spent 2 hours exploring it, full of history. A must see when in Lausanne.

Sounds like an Estee Lauder's ad : what did indeed happen to Lausanne cathedral, a much loved stopover by medieval & nowadays pilgrims across Europe - 40 years long restoration leading to a resplendent Montfalcon (main) portal with dazzlingly cleaned, almost wedding-cake (but
Very beautiful old historic church on the top of one of the hills in Lausanne with an impressive interior and great views of the city outside.

This cathedral is huge and very nice from both inside and outside but for me the highlight is to go to the top of the campanile because the view from the top is absolutely great. Hard work but certainly worth the ciews
Lovely gothic architecture and beautiful coloured stained glass windows. Lovely view of Lausanne and the lake from the view point outside the cathedral.
The cathedral and the city centre are close and makes a worthwhile trip. Nice atmosphere, beautiful stained glass and overall feeling is great.
I liked the clean soaring lines of the structure. No need for frescoes that flake and fade. Simplicity.

I grew up here and took my classes around the corner. We used to hang out in the Cathedral between classes to study. This is a beautiful gothic cathedral, used by many, and relatively unspoiled by the tourist trade. I still feel a reverence every time I walk through it. Outside,
The facade of the cathedral is enormously beautiful and magnificent. Very good architectural accomplishment.
After checking into our hotel, we headed for this cathedral. It is known throughout Europe and I suppose that is due to its size. It is very large. The stained glass windows are lovely.
The Old Town of Lausanne has imposing buildings dating back to the Middle Ages such as the famous Cathedral of Norte-Dame. It was build between 1397-1427. It is impressive and interesting to view.

We visited the cathedral while in Lussanne. It is a large beautiful cathedral. Stained glass windows are beautiful.From the central square you need to climb up a number of wooden steps to reach the cathedral.Free to enter but to go up the tower u have to pay(we didnt go up)
Very nice walk to reach the Cathedral. The monument itself is astonishing and it is totally worth visiting! Just nearby there is a very nice view and chill after the long walk to reach the place :)
Easily accessible by metro. Beautiful interior. When we arrive, there was an ongoing service but we we allowed to go in.

We came upon this cathedral by pure accident after alighting from getting off the free train and walking up the steep steps. We walked across the quite small look out area over the town with the mountains in the distance and decided to look around the cathedral. Though
I didn't particularly enjoy the cathedral itself, what I enjoyed was getting up the stairs to the top and then having a stunning view of Lausanne.
lots to read - in German, French and English - fantastic views and gorgeous cathedral. A must-see. Give it a few hours to appreciate everything.

The building is really huge, and gothic in all its details. The ornaments above the entrance are a replica of the original which had been destroyed. This is clearly visible, because the colour is quite different from the rest of the church. The exterior is magnificent,

Take a trip to this cathedral with the walking tour offered by Town Hall i.e. Lausanne en pied. They tell you a lot about the history of this church. Note that at the entrance, there are some beheaded sculptures of Marie, and the walls were colorful which was painted grey
Beautiful and tranquil but the walk up is not for the faint hearted. However the view is amazing over the city. Those with children should visit the little toy shop close by also.
This ancient castle is one of the largest in Switzerland. The views from this Cathedral are stunniing.
The cathedral is a beautiful building set amidst serene surroundings. The view of the lake & surrounding buildings from the forecourt is simply amazing!

A most austere and marvelous cathedral, this piece of architecture dominates Lausanne and marks the entrance of the medieval Lausanne. The interior and newly restored outside is very elegant and speaks forcefully about the idea of the austerity of Protestantism of the Canton de
We are not really into Cathedrals but if in the area, this is surely one place to visit. The architecture is amazing and the organ is very impressive.
Surely cathedral in this country cannot be compared with those magnificent ones in Italy or France. But this one in Lausanne is another beauty. The colour glass windows are surely lovely.
Cathedral should be visited if in town. Lovely organ play, great view and glass windows are worth a look.
Unique experience. The cathedral can be seen from every corner of the city. Incredible acoustics, unbelievable the sound of the organ..
Beautiful Cathedral, great views and lovely buildings all around. If you can’t manage the steps there is a lift in the library.
Easy access using the tram, built many centuries ago, its another architectural marvel. The view from the surrounding is breath taking. One can get a panoramic view of Lausanne and Lake Geneva.

Intersesting and amazing carving on the building and the grand doors...Unfortunately we visited at night and could not see inside but to think this magnificient architecture was built prior to modern machines is mind boggling

The Cathedrale de Lausanne is absolutely beautiful. Its architecture is unsurpassed in the city with an inner space that is grand and yet not losing its reverence. Be sure to walk around the cathedral to experience its different chambers.

The cathedral is easy to get to via bus or metro and is free to enter. The gothic  exterior needs to be appreciated as does the interior and not rushed so plan ahead to spend some time here. The craftsmanship inside and out is stunning. Its worth noting that the cathedral is

There is no better way to experience Lausanne than a walking tour of the city center and the Cathedral is a perfect spot to start the tour. From the Cathedral, you can decent to the market following Escaliers du Marche, which takes you directly to the heart of the market where

Best view in Laussane! Enjoy walking, beautiful place, nice jogging too. Love this place so much. If you go to Laussane, you can't miss this place which offer the excellent city view, see my photos here in the review.
The cathedrale is one of many. It delivers the same experience as if you were to visit a similar style cathedrale. The view, however is very nice. You can see all over Lausanne from the look-out.
Great cathedral with lots of history although it's not richly decorated since it's pretty. Must see at Lausanne!
Very beautiful. You must go. Here is a way for wheelchair and baby carts. The vitrais and amazing and he architecture is unique. You must pass by this cathedral if you visit Lausanne. *****

The cathedral itself is lovely, but it's really worth paying to go to the top (you do have to climb a few stairs). The views over Lausanne are beautiful.
Beautiful gothic cathedral. Fantastic stained glass windows. Was really big inside. We also saw the christmas exhibition with the lovely models.

There many ways to reach this wonderful cathedral (Escaliers du Marche, Pont Charles Bessieres…), but from all points it looks equally beautiful and harmonic. Actually, one can spend the whole day there, looking at it’s statues, decorations and glass windows. And the view over

The history and gob smacking lead lighting and architecture make this one of the most interesting cathedral finds of my holiday. I went to Notre Dame, Milan's Duomo and San Marco's et al in Venice and this certainly was special.

Great old-mystic looking church almost like ones you find in movies and games. Hadn't been to the tower but the balcony just outside the door also gave a good view of the city. This place needs English signs and description to let people appreciate this place even more.
This is true historical site. But one would like to see more English and German descriptions etc. Lausanne needs to present its gems to more than a Francophone audience.

A huge cathedral, with an almost ''scary'' entrance, a big black curtine after the big heavy door .... the inside part makes you feel that you are not in today... amazing windows and impressive sound in the cathedral. You have to visit this place.

We are Christians and enjoy seeing how Christian worship spaces vary around the world. This one was memorable, notably for the beautiful stained-glass windows of the church and the high arches over the nave.

Lausanne on a Sunday shuts down! With only 1 day there I was happy we could see the cathedral. There are many many steps leading up to it but if you take them slowly and remember the history behind them, it makes it interesting. The cathedral is in the gothic style and more

Absolutely worth the trip and easy to get to from Lausanne Port d'Ouchy via metro the Cathedral is breath taking and the acoustics are amazing. For a few euros, you can go into the little gift shop and buy a ticket to climb to the top of the tower and look at the bells. They
The cathedral in itself is just beautiful. You really should go in and visit it, for a few coins you can also climb the stairs to the top and have one of the most wonderful views of the city.

They were renovating parts of the cathedral when we visited but the stained glass windows and stonework around the main door is worth seeing. The cathedral has a dark gothic feel which the stained glass emphasises. Outside it is worth a wander around to see the view of the
It is worth the visit. Special place to enjoy for few hours. Take a audio guide if you want to worth it.

We walked all the way up to the cathedral, and then up to the top of the bell tower. View from the top of the stairs by the church was awesome, but if you are dating enough to go up the bell tower, it’s totally worth it. Beautiful views all around. Only 5 SF to walk up.

If you're in the area it's worth a visit to see the stained glass windows and explanations of some of the stone carvings. There is also a good lookout over the city near the front entrance. I wouldn't make a trip specifically to see it though.

During mw trip in Swizerland, my native friend of Lausanne suggest me to visit the cathedrale de Lausanne (i'm a fan of religious monument), and i wasn't disappointed at all. After climbing (too) many step, we stop at the top and the price was very grateful. Indeed, the
The church is very nice and well maintenance. Only a few minutes walk from metro station and you could see panoramic view of the city.

We did our own walking tour and made our way to the cathedral. Would have been better to join a tour and have someone give us history, but the beauty is enough. Great panoramic view of the city outside the cathedral.

I walked here. The walk is lovely walking up many steps. The streets are cobblestone and have great views of Lausanne. I was too late for the tower and it is only 5 francs. The church is lovely inside, and I enjoyed sitting in serenity.

Spoke to a wonderful cathedral guide, who was very knowledgable and helpful. Told us the Cathedral was designed by the same architect who designed Canterbury Cathedral. The organ is amazing.....unfortunately not in use when we were there. I would have loved to have had a
This was my first Swiss cathedral -- I wasn't sure what to expect with all the Catholic trappings stripped out by the Protestants (centuries ago). It's lovely.

Beautiful cathedral high on a hill overlooking Lausanne. Wonderful stained glass windows and a real sense of history. Quite and peaceful site and a great place from which to get a perspective of the city. Well worth the climb up all those stairs
Beautiful chuch in the center of Lausanne. this church is very quiet and nice. I recommand the visit of this church if you are in Lausanne.

Nice cathedral sitting tall on the vertical city of Lausanne, Canton of Vaud. Renovation going on inside. There is guided tour for a fee. Also there is a nominal fee to climb to the top of the bell tower which provides sweeping panoramic view of the lake geneva on one side and
If you have a spare hour or so the Cathedral building and windows is interesting and its location on a hill with great views over the city

If you've visited lots of churches recently, then this one is nothing special. If not, make sure you visit it. It's located above the hill. So put the building aside, you can enjoy the panaromic views of lausanne.
Located in the old town, nice walk around and if you are lucky, you might end up listening a gospel or classic music concert over there..

An impressive cathedral, definitely worth checking this out. The stained glass windows inside were breathtaking.
Very imposing structure, the cathedral spires are visible from a distance. Inside are stained glass windows and paintings of the scripture on the walls. A solemn place of worship steeped in history.

Huge cathedrals usually make me unconfortable, not this one. On the contrary. The art, the light, the colors, all is easy on the eye and on the mind. I felt peaceful and spent a surprisingly long time there. The small room on the right side of the entrance looks a bit russian.
The statuary at the entrance was the best part for me. The interior is not ornate except some of the stained glass and the magnificent organ. We didn't climb the tower.

Nice church close to old Lausanne. The stained glass work throughout the cathedral is spectacular. The church is world renowned for his amazing and huge organ. The pipes of the organs are arranged to look like an angel with open wings.

The cathedral is absolutely stunning - the stained glass windows alone were worth the visit and the interior of the church is breathtaking. Tours are available at various points during the day, free of charge.

Fabulous old cathedral with attractive stained glass windows in the old quarter of Lausanne. A short walk from one of the main market squares the setting could be straight out of a film set. Some quaint restaurants and bars nearby.

Beautiful stained-glass windows, stone carvings, a tower to climb for a view all over town. See the organ, with more than 7000 pipes and 6 keyboards, played in the organ loft or on the movable electronic console in the nave. Recitals generally Friday evenings, with guest
The cathedral is considered one of the most beautiful gothic buildings in Switzerland. Don't miss the panoramic view!!! (5 euros to go to the top).
It is a lovely cathedral but quite a hike to get up to it! Most of this town is 'up or down' an it si worth the effort

I went in at a time when there weren't many people. The place felt like the way I feel Cathedrals are supposed to feel like: quiet and full of prayer. It's calm. From up the bell tower the view is fantastic.

Visited with friends with small children, we went up the bell tower in absolute safety. From that stand point the view is breathtaking. Don't miss the interior of the dome, especially the world class pipe organ. If you have the cha, stay for a concert: the sound is rich and
Calm, restful, gentle.. no big tourist spaces, a place of peace in the middle of the city.. lovely place of contemplation
Very pretty and large cathedral up on the hill in the old section of Lausanne. Beautiful view from up there.

This is a huge cavernous church with very special bell tower. There are very many steps to climb up to the top of the bell tower but the views you get up there are worth every step of the way! We were very fortunate to have an organ player to sit and listen to for a while.

In comparison in other counties sacral monument places Lausanne cathedral seems to be rather sad and empty place. Perhaps joining guided tour could change my impression as I visited it myself. Free entrance was an advantage.

The Cathedral was closed when I got there Friday morning. There was a sign that it was reopening at 2:00 PM, but I missed my chance to see the inside. The outside is lovely, especially at night from our room!

The Catedral are doing fixed, but its a good place to visit. In the way, you can see beautiful gardens and you can take a lot of photos to register this moment. In the same place, its possible to see part of the city in a vantage vision.
In comparison to Italy or Spain's cathedrals, this is far less impressive. It has magnificent view from outside, but inside does not impress at all.

We walked in to the cathedral just as a service was about to begin. The service was simple, the pastor gentle and the gathered devout. After the service, walked around reading the different elements about the church.

It's a lovely church with fascinating mixture of styles indicating various historical periods. Do pay to go up the tower. If you have any interest in history or want a great view it's worth the climb.
If you're in the general vicinity, I'd recommend a trip to the cathedral - even if a brief one. There are some seriously impressive stained glass windows along with the historic architecture.

Right now (June 2017), this cathedral is under renovation so many parts are closed off. When everything is completed, I am sure that it will be a stunning sight to see and experience...to bad I am already home from vacationing in Switzerland.

This church was a beautiful church high up on the hill. It took some walking and time to get there. It was a beautiful view of the city from there however. The Chateau nearby was under reconstruction unfortunately.

We visited the Cathedral as part of a stroll through the Old Town. Fascinating historically and very peaceful,if you want period of quiet reflection. Absolutely magnificent stained glass windows, worth the visit in themselves.

Until I saw the sign I didnt realise there were more than one Notre Dame Cathedral but this is an amazingly beautiful cathedral even if it shares a name with others. Love the big circular Window at the front and all the decorative architecture

You can see this Cathedral from the train that I used to take from Geneva to Zermatt. That train has amazing views of Lausanne, A town which housed Audrey Hepburn for the last 30 years of her life. The town looked just like her, from the train, --elegant, polished and slightly

After taking the metro up the number of hills in Lausanne. We arrived at this amazing Cathedrale.It is free to enter. The stain glass windows are great. I did return that night to hear the night watchman do hour call

Its a beautiful 800 year old cathedral also known as Notre Dame of Laussanne. Its easily accessible by the metro station Riponne-M Bejart. Also from behind the Cathedral there is a short-cut passage to the Musee de History.
The walk to get here is quite an odysey, as you have to walk a lot of stairs up in order to get there. However once you get there. There is a nice museum next to it.

the Cathedral was built catholic and was later converted when the reform hit Lausanne. Today it is a very well maintained building with a lot of reading in the inner part of it. Very stripped "dépouillé", it has kept all of its original features and gained as well a lot of
Well worth the trip up to see it. A fairly plain cathedral that has had a lot of work done on it. Wonderful views from here.
The top of the cathedral offers a great view of Lausanne. This is not the nicest cathedral, but it is still worth the trip for the nice view. There is a small fee to get on top of the tower.

To reach the cathedral you have to go up more than 300 stair steps approximately , where is was so stressful as the Cathedral is located on top of the hill. From the high point of the Cathedral you can have a full view over all of the City Lausanne I mean the old town.

Lausanne Peak with wonderful view on the terrace. The interior of the Cathedral is amazing, very simple and beautiful. The organ with horizontal trumpets is most impressive. Summer shelter from the heat and a place to rest and pray.
The entrance is free And sometimes depending on the period you are in Lausanne there are some events held in it; like concerts, get informed from the nearest tourist office.
We came too late to go in Cathedrale but a view on the city is beautiful! You can use stairs that are going from Public library to the Cathedrale, it is 5min walk uphill.
It's on the top of Lausanne and you can see it from the Hotel Regina. You can walk through the city to reach the cathedral. It's historical.
The cathedral is quite spectacular, the architecture, organ and stained glass windows were amazing. I've visited quite a few cathedrals and this definitely stands out as one of the most impressive.

A very nice Cathedral with a fantastic view of Lausanne.... and the mountains, the lake ... Its well worth a visit - don't miss it ! Explore the inner city around this place with nice little Café houses. Use the Metro to go to this place.
Very nice Cathedral with breathtaking view of Lausanne and surroundings. Protestant Place, so no saints and stuff inside.
Well worth a visit. Take Metro up hill from train station. Beautiful colourful windows. Views of Lausanne from top well worth the visit
Great view from the top and interesting exhibitions about the cathedral as you climb to the top. I was lucky to hear a concert on the organ, unforgettable.

Impressive building on the top of the city. If you are fit I recommend you to walk up to the Cathedral from La Place de La Palud. Is the spiritual capital of the French speaking part of Switzerland. In the inside you can see all the polychromy. Very nice view to the city from

Good to walk up here on a sunny day. Try to walk on up via Escaliers du Marche. The Lausanne Cathedral itself is very nice and need a walk thru the interior. But the view outside is even better. The local offers a good view of the whole town and the lake.
Go, the artwork, story and view is absolutely stunning ! It is fascinating to se such a huge church in the center of Lausanne !
Quite beautiful inside the cathedral in a gothic style. Free entry and photos allowed. Difficult to find parking around the area.

The Cathedrale is the crown jewel of the Old City or La Cité of Lausanne and is considered to be one of the finest examples of Gothic architecture in Europe. It is right in the Centre and so it makes for a very nice part of a walk about the downtown area. I highly recommend it.
Magnificent Cathedral with beautiful stained coloured glasses. A jewel from the Past. A must-see visit of the large old city.
The church is huge, imposing and is located in a hill that has a nice view to the city. However, inside it`s just ok. It worth going there, but lower your expectations and enjoy the view.
The catedral is a very pure early gothic style, very harmonious and perfectily restored, a visit is a must. And the nave is very impressive. Also the stained-glass-windows are beautiful.

This was a great quick stop in Lausanne. I would recommend a visit here for sure. The church was beautiful and had free entry. The belfry tower does cost money and we did t have time to make the climb up. Perhaps next visit.

Must-see spot for travelers to Lausanne. It will relax your mind after a walk or climb from the ground.
Beautiful views of the city - bring your camera; beautiful stained glass; so much history and worth the trek.

If you climb the Belfry tower, you can get the most breathtaking views of Lausanne! Definitely an activity for a nice day. Also, entry to the cathedral is free and you can see the beautiful stained glass windows, but even entry to the tower is super cheap- only 3fr for a student
