Thus is a "must see" place in Lausanne. The monument is great and the surrounding is also a charm. The terrace in front of the catheral has a great view on the Leman lake and the roofs of Lausanne.
It's an historical site, with imponent tube organs, amazing vitrals and ancient cripts. Unfortunately the ice in the stairs disabled us for visiting the tower. It's pending!
Well worth a visit. This is a beautiful cathedral with an excellent view of the city. The windows are spectacular. The stone work is amazing.

We arrived at night but the building was shiny and colourful due to the flood lights and the view above the hilly Lausanne was still enjoyable and great. We had to search for restaurants at that time and were happy to find Café l'eveche right around the corner.

This is not a "glitzy" cathedral covered in murals and mosaics like some. As a result you appreciate the beauty of the architecture of the building more. The view of Lake Geneva from the top is also amazing.
Amazing building, amazing atmosphere and amazing view once you get to the top! as everything in lausanne, the view is always a big plus!
As an Orthodox Christian, I was interesting to look at the cathedral. The building from the outside is very beautiful with this Gothic style.
stunning inside. climb the stairs and you will get to the top, for a chance to admire the city and the lake.

On a sunny day the cathedral looks sparkling and bright. The architecture inside and out is beautiful and the colours in the glass look amazing. This cathedral puts the cathedral in Geneva to shame....that one is grey and cold. We all thoroughly enjoyed our visit to Lausanne

Wander around inside and enjoy the atmosphere. Think back many centuries d think of the vision and craftsmanship it would take to build something so grand. To enter is free. Go slowly. Pause to look at the stained glass windows.

While visiting Lausanne with my family we made our way up the hill to the cathedral. After walking around the exterior we made our way inside and noticed that tours were available of the bell tour and crypt. Our guide took our family down through the locked gate to the crypt.
Fab views of Lausanne from outside, warm and welcoming inside. Lovely cafe doing hot chocolates just below

The cathedral is supposed to be the finest Gothic building in Switzerland. It is a beautiful building. Besides religious services there a numerous concerts that are played here. There's a 7,000 pipe organ here. I didn't climb the tower but the views from outside the cathedral

If you're in Lausanne and you like this kind of monuments... You must arrange some time to walk in the streets near the cathedral and visit it. I woul recommend to check if any concert is scheduled. The cathedral has a huge Iberia pipe organ and concerts usual.

magnificent! austere, but full of magic. with a marvelous view of the city...take a walk around the old city to reach the castle...

It is very sad to hear about the wonderful decorations and colors which were purposely taken down by the austere protestants taking over from the Catholics. There is a special room for pilgrims which is worth visiting and a tomb with an unusual story as well as spectacular

From the moment you enter this cathedral you are gripped by its history. Building started in the 12th Century and its antiquity is evident. That said you can see the evidence of its development over the centuries with a magnificent new organ taking centre stage. A place of peace

It is just great, especially the tower: it has several levels and it's kinda scary to climb it. Keep in mind that the tower is only open during certain hours, and from 2pm on Sunday, so plan in advance. The view from the tower is just great.

Travelling around Switzerland we decided to stop in the beautiful city of Lausanne. We made a bee-line, albeit a slow one, for the Cathedral. What we didn't realise is the size of the climb and the number of steps we would have to ascend. When we got there the cathedral is
A lovely Cathedral. Recommend the tower 5SF. The views are excellent. The original main door with statutes of saints is lovely.
A beautiful cathedral in a lovely town on the lake. A lovely, peaceful place in which to reflect and contemplate.
very beautiful, one of the key attractions in lausanne as it stands out in the city that you cannot miss!
The front entrance is gorgeous!! The front doors are tall and detailed... it overlooks the entire town, lake and mountains. The organ inside is impressive.

We spent a few hours in Lausanne for a day trip from Paris. The historic old town is great and the Rick Steve's recommended walk ends up by the cathedral. It wasn't open, but the exterior was great. Only issue is the public restrooms behind it. Dirty and disgusting.
Beautiful cathedral, amazing terrace quth view over Lausanne and french mountains. They often organize concerts and events inside
The cathedral is nice to see. From inside it is a beautiful church, but not very special. Outside you have a nice lookout over the city.
I visited Cathedrale de Lausanne 2 times during my stay. It's really beautiful without the crowds! Love it!

A wonderful building with an exceptional and unusual modern organ and a beautiful stained glass rose window. Lots of history, a tower to go up if you're feeling like climbing and a fantastic view up and down the lake and across the city on a good day.

There are so many in Europe, but this is a real beauty, on a hilltop overlooking the city. Easy metro or bus ride up. Other sights nearby.

We visited as part of a walking tour through the city (well recommended). As such we learnt a lot about the history and got some very detailed explanations about the stained glass windows - rare form with square and circles as well as the portal. Certainly a must-see
Visited the cathedral briefly. The cathedral itself is magnificent, and the view earned from climbing from the surprisingly easy staircase is tremendous

We enjoyed walking to the Cathedrale from our hotel. The area surrounding it has an incredible view of the city. Inside, they are doing a bit of construction so that might be a distraction. It is still very lovely. I would go back.

Gorgeous red and yellow stained glass windows over the west doors. Esp at sunset! The organ is gorgeous as well. The organist can actually sit at the movable keyboard anywhere in the church. Way cool technology.
Beatiful cathedral close to the center of city and nice view on it. Unfortunately is now in reconstruction from outside. Inside beautiful building!
Very interesting historic building. We were lucky enough to experience a young organist practising on what looks like a relatively new pipe organ. Wonderful.
The walk up to the top of the tower of the cathedral and view the sights. The kids loved it! A little steep in places, but gorgeous.
I the heart of the old town.Beautifully kept, not too large or small.One of the nicest Cathedrals in Switzerland. Surrounded by winding streets and shops a fairy tale to visit

This is a very lovely peaceful cathedral. Walking inside just gives you a sence of calmness and peace. It's stained glass is breathtaking. make sure you look up towards the organ at the back of the cathedral - above the door entrance. Simply divine.
A must-see for sure if you visit Lausanne. The view from the cathedral is great- being on a hill, the city view is quite nice.

Lovely gothic cathedral on the top of Lausanne. The stairs will do you good but, the views from the top makes it all worth while. Absolutely beautiful! Do go if you get the chance. A lovely little traditional cafe mid stairs as well :)

The location is at the heart of the city. Elevated. Great views of city. Walks around the cathedral with bars, cafes, little galleries etc. A good open air cafe just near the steps leading up to it from the Riponne Square (and history museum). Lovely cathedral. Fascinating

There are not many places to visit in this town and this is biggest and best church to visit. There is another one St Francis that is also easy to visit both would take less than an hour. The waterfront walk is best part of Lausanne
It is small and not exuberant, but for people loving churches it is a good visit. I would recommend going up the tower to see the view.

If you are visiting Lausanne, then you will eventually find yourself at the cathedral. Very impressive building, but be prepared to walk uphill! The cathedral is at the top of the steep hill on which the city is built.
Lots of stairs to get up to it, but it is BEAUTIFUL! I wouldn't take young kids, but 8+ years should be fine. Go see it! The windows are amazing!

The cathedral is a interesting place to visit, considering the location and other things you can do nearby. However, it has different art styles at the same building (it might be confusing if you pay attention to the details).
Majestic cathedral with great stained glass and very interesting organ parts of which have a horizontal pipes. Nice view of Lausanne from place nearby.

Very interesting to visit in Lausanne. Impressive middle-age (gothic) architecture. Original sculptures, stainglass scene, funeral stones of bishops and nobility. A interesting piece af history. We loved. We appreciated the free leaflets in different languages.

It Was a visit to thé cathédrale in laussane I went with my teen-ager They were intrsted when they sow thé old cathadthdral We toke photos And thats Was déferrant

Nice place. After the walt in a big city we were glad to clibe up and spend few hour o the top Lausanne.

This was a very good tour and well worth it to go with a group to hear about the history of it. When we got there we got to go to the front of the line cause of the tickets we had gotten and the tour we were on. The cathedral is amazing.
Impressive cathedral. If you have little time and want to visit one famous building in Lausanne this is the one to pick!
cathedral is very well kept, it has an amazing new organ. The view from the patio in from of the cathedral is stunning- you can see the whole city

Historically impressive, lovely outside. But a cold spirit overall inside. Maybe it's the weather? An under leveraged, under appreciated tourism asset.

Nice place but it was closed when we were visiting. Nearby there are plenty of places for shopping and shopping centers so that the atmosphere is complete.

A very good place to visit with a nice view over the city. You can see that it is not a flat city :-)

This is the biggest in Switzerland, it's very nice. Especially the windows are very very pretty. The view is amazing, you can look out ove Lausanne

Lots to look at, lovely & interesting stained-glass windows! The view from the terrace down to the city & lake, with the Alps in the background, is breathtaking

Excellent views over the old town from cathedral close, and a spacious building inside with a considerable amount of impressive stained glass

After traveling through Italy and France where the cathedrals are very ornate it was nice to visit a cathedral with beautiful arches and stained glass that was not too over the top.

Big cathedral. There are wonderful big stained glass so you need to go inside during a sunny day. Inside is without sculptures and pictures.
This Cathedrale in Lausanne is really wonderful. You can see the different colourful windows. And you don't have to pay an admission fee.

One of the most imposing attractions from Lausanne that is really nice to have a look at it. Still need to make some exercise to get to it being situated on top of a hill from where you can see the beauty of city.

High above the town (Lausanne is all up and down). The Cathedral is a must see. Lovely stained glass.

text.wiki:
Outsider art is art by self-taught or naïve art makers. Typically, those labeled as outsider artists have little or no contact with the mainstream art world or art institutions. In many cases, their work is discovered only after their deaths. Often, outsider art illustrates extreme mental states, unconventional ideas, or elaborate fantasy worlds.
The term outsider art was coined by art critic Roger Cardinal in 1972 as an English synonym for art brut (French: [aʁ bʁyt], "raw art" or "rough art"), a label created by French artist Jean Dubuffet to describe art created outside the boundaries of official culture; Dubuffet focused particularly on art by those on the outside of the established art scene, using as examples psychiatric hospital patients and children.Outsider art has emerged as a successful art marketing category; an annual Outsider Art Fair has taken place in New York since 1993, and there are at least two regularly published journals dedicated to the subject. The term is sometimes misapplied as a catch-all marketing label for art created by people who are outside the mainstream "art world" or "art gallery system", regardless of their circumstances or the content of their work. A more specific term, "outsider music", was later adapted for musicians.


== Art of the mentally ill ==

Interest in the art of the mentally ill, along with that of children and the makers of "peasant art", was first demonstrated by "Der Blaue Reiter" group: Wassily Kandinsky, Auguste Macke, Franz Marc, Alexej Jawlensky, and others. What the artists perceived in the work of these groups was an expressive power born of their perceived lack of sophistication. Examples of this were reproduced in 1912 in the first and only issue of their publication, Der Blaue Reiter Almanac. During World War I, Macke was killed at Champagne in 1914 and Marc was killed at Verdun in 1916; the gap left by these deaths was to some extent filled by Paul Klee, who continued to draw inspiration from these 'primitives'.
Interest in the art of insane asylum inmates continued to grow in the 1920s. In 1921, Dr. Walter Morgenthaler published his book Ein Geisteskranker als Künstler (A Psychiatric Patient as Artist) about Adolf Wölfli, a psychotic mental patient in his care. Wölfli had spontaneously taken up drawing, and this activity seemed to calm him. His most outstanding work was an illustrated epic of 45 volumes in which he narrated his own imaginary life story. With 25,000 pages, 1,600 illustrations, and 1,500 collages, it is a monumental work. Wölfli also produced a large number of smaller works, some of which were sold or given as gifts. His work is on display at the Adolf Wölfli Foundation in the Museum of Fine Art, Bern.
A defining moment was the publication of Bildnerei der Geisteskranken (Artistry of the Mentally Ill) in 1922, by Hans Prinzhorn. This was the first formal study of psychiatric works, based upon a compilation of thousands of examples from European institutions. The book and the art collection gained much attention from avant-garde artists of the time, including Paul Klee, Max Ernst, and Jean Dubuffet.People with some formal artistic training as well as well-established artists are not immune from mental illness, and may also be institutionalized. For example, William Kurelek, later awarded the Order of Canada for his artistic life work, as a young man was admitted to the Maudsley Psychiatric Hospital where he was treated for schizophrenia. In hospital he painted, producing The Maze, a dark depiction of his tortured youth. He was transferred from the Maudsley to Netherne Hospital from November 1953 to January 1955, to work with Edward Adamson (1911–1996), a pioneer of art therapy, and creator of the Adamson Collection.


== Jean Dubuffet and art brut ==

French artist Jean Dubuffet was particularly struck by Bildnerei der Geisteskranken and began his own collection of such art, which he called art brut or raw art. In 1948 he formed the Compagnie de l'Art Brut along with other artists, including André Breton. The collection he established became known as the Collection de l'art brut. It contains thousands of works and is now permanently housed in Lausanne, Switzerland.
Dubuffet characterized art brut as: 

"Those works created from solitude and from pure and authentic creative impulses – where the worries of competition, acclaim and social promotion do not interfere – are, because of these very facts, more precious than the productions of professionals. After a certain familiarity with these flourishings of an exalted feverishness, lived so fully and so intensely by their authors, we cannot avoid the feeling that in relation to these works, cultural art in its entirety appears to be the game of a futile society, a fallacious parade." — Jean Dubuffet. Place à l'incivisme (Make way for Incivism). Art and Text no.27 (December 1987 – February 1988). p.36  Dubuffet's writing on art brut was the subject of a noted program at the Art Club of Chicago in the early 1950s.Dubuffet argued that 'culture', that is mainstream culture, managed to assimilate every new development in art, and by doing so took away whatever power it might have had. The result was to asphyxiate genuine expression. Art brut was his solution to this problem – only art brut was immune to the influences of culture, immune to being absorbed and assimilated, because the artists themselves were not willing or able to be assimilated.


== Cultural context ==
The interest in "outsider" practices among twentieth-century artists and critics can be seen as part of a larger emphasis on the rejection of established values within the modernist art milieu. The early part of the 20th century gave rise to Cubism and the Dada, Constructivist and Futurist movements in art, all of which involved a dramatic movement away from cultural forms of the past. Dadaist Marcel Duchamp, for example, abandoned "painterly" technique to allow chance operations a role in determining the form of his works, or simply to re-contextualize existing "readymade" objects as art. Mid-century artists, including Pablo Picasso, looked outside the traditions of high culture for inspiration, drawing from the artifacts of "primitive" societies, the unschooled artwork of children, and vulgar advertising graphics. Dubuffet's championing of the art brut – of the insane and others at the margins of society – is yet another example of avant-garde art challenging established cultural values.


== Terminology ==

A number of terms are used to describe art that is loosely understood as "outside" of official culture.  Definitions of these terms vary and overlap.  The editors of Raw Vision, a leading journal in the field, suggest that "Whatever views we have about the value of controversy itself, it is important to sustain creative discussion by way of an agreed vocabulary". Consequently, they lament the use of "outsider artist" to refer to almost any untrained artist. "It is not enough to be untrained, clumsy or naïve. Outsider Art is virtually synonymous with Art Brut in both spirit and meaning, to that rarity of art produced by those who do not know its name."

Art Brut: literally translated from French means "raw art";  'Raw' in that it has not been through the 'cooking' process: the world of art schools, galleries, museums. Originally art by psychotic individuals who existed almost completely outside culture and society. Strictly speaking it refers only to the Collection de l'art brut.
Folk art: Folk art originally suggested crafts and decorative skills associated with peasant communities in Europe – though presumably it could equally apply to any indigenous culture. It has broadened to include any product of practical craftsmanship and decorative skill – everything from chain-saw animals to hub-cap buildings. A key distinction between folk and outsider art is that folk art typically embodies traditional forms and social values, where outsider art stands in some marginal relationship to society's mainstream.
Intuitive art/Visionary art: Raw Vision Magazine's preferred general terms for outsider art. It describes them as deliberate umbrella terms. However, Visionary Art unlike other definitions here can often refer to the subject matter of the works, which includes images of a spiritual or religious nature. Intuitive art is probably the most general term available. Intuit: The Center for Intuitive and Outsider Art based in Chicago operates a museum dedicated to the study and exhibition of intuitive and outsider art.  The American Visionary Art Museum in Baltimore, Maryland is dedicated to the collection and display of visionary art.
Marginal art/Art singulier: Essentially the same as Neuve Invention; refers to artists on the margins of the art world.
Naïve art: Another term commonly applied to untrained artists who aspire to "normal" artistic status, i.e. they have a much more conscious interaction with the mainstream art world than do outsider artists.
Neuve invention: Used to describe artists who, although marginal, have some interaction with mainstream culture. They may be doing art part-time for instance. The expression was coined by Dubuffet too; strictly speaking it refers only to a special part of the Collection de l'art brut.
Visionary environments: Buildings and sculpture parks built by visionary artists – range from decorated houses, to large areas incorporating a large number of individual sculptures with a tightly associated theme. Examples include Watts Towers by Simon Rodia, Buddha Park and Sala Keoku by Bunleua Sulilat, and The Palais Ideal by Ferdinand Cheval.


== Notable outsider artists ==
Nick Blinko (born 1961) is an English musician and artist diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder. He is represented in the Collection de l'art brut in Lausanne. He is best known through his works with his band Rudimentary Peni.

Sid Boyum (1914–1991) was an industrial photographer who turned his home and yard into a vast, dense array of concrete and wood sculptures, many of which have since been moved to public locations throughout his neighborhood in Madison, Wisconsin.
Al Carbee (1914–2005) was a prolific, multi-format artist who is known for his Barbie collages. Carbee created a massive imaginary utopia with his collages, which he called "Epicuma". When Carbee was in his 80s, his art was discovered accidentally by filmmaker Jeremy Workman, leading to a flurry of interest in his later years. Carbee was the subject of Workman's documentary film Magical Universe.
Benny Carter (1943–2014) was an American artist known for his paintings of New York City and rural North Carolina.
James Charles Castle (1899-1977) was a self-taught artist from Garden Valley, Idaho.
Nek Chand (1924–2015) was an Indian artist, famous for building the Rock Garden of Chandigarh, a forty-acre (160,000 m2) sculpture garden in the city of Chandigarh, India.
Ferdinand Cheval (1836–1924) was a country postman in Hauterives, south of Lyon, France. Motivated by a dream, he spent 33 years constructing the Palais Ideal. Half organic building, half massive sculpture, it was constructed from stones collected on his postal round, held together with chicken wire, cement, and lime.
Felipe Jesus Consalvos (1891–c. 1960) was a Cuban-American cigar roller and artist, known for his posthumously discovered body of art work based on the vernacular tradition of cigar band collage.
Richard Dadd (1817–1886), noted for his depictions of fairies and other supernatural subjects, rendered with obsessively minuscule detail. Most of the works for which he is best known were created while he was a patient in Bethlem and Broadmoor psychiatric hospitals.
Henry Darger (1892–1973) was a solitary man who was orphaned and institutionalized as a child. In the privacy of his small north side Chicago apartment, he produced over 35,000 pages of text and hundreds of large scale illustrations, including maps, collaged photos, and watercolors that depict the heroic struggles of his child characters, "the Vivian Girls", engaged in activities such as battle scenes combining imagery of the US Civil War with the presence of fanciful monsters.
Terry A. Davis (1969-2018), a schizophrenic computer programmer and creator of TempleOS.
Charles Dellschau (1830–1923) born in Prussia, Dellschau emigrated to the US and in his 70s secluded himself in an attic and over the course of 20 years created 12 large scale books filled with mixed media watercolors depicting the inventions of the Sonora Aero Club, chronicling the birth of the age of aviation. It is unknown if his subject was factual, a fictionalization or a delusion.
Holly Farrell, 21st century Canadian self taught artist whose paintings include the Barbie & Ken series, is considered an Outsider artist.
Madge Gill (1882–1961) was an English mediumistic artist who made thousands of drawings "guided" by a spirit she called "Myrninerest" (my inner rest).
Paul Gösch (1885–1940), a schizophrenic German artist and architect murdered by the Nazis in their euthanasia campaign.
James Hampton (1909–1964) was an African-American janitor who secretly built a large assemblage of religious art from scavenged materials, such as discarded light bulbs and aluminum foil
Annie Hooper (1897–1986), a sculptor of visionary religious art from Buxton, North Carolina, who created nearly 5,000 sculptures depicting biblical scenes. Her work is now in the permanent collection of North Carolina State University.
Georgiana Houghton (1814–1884), a British spiritualist medium, known for her visionary 'spirit drawings', consisting of intricate abstract watercolours.
Vojislav Jakic (1932–2003), a Serbian artist who spent most of his life in a small town of Despotovac producing drawings up to five meters long evoking the memories of his own life, his obsessions with death, and reflections on art. His works mix abstraction and graphic signs and writings.
Mollie Jenson (1890–1973) created a series of large-scale concrete sculptures embellished with tile mosaics in River Falls, Wisconsin.
Daniel Johnston (1961-2019) a lo-fi musician with schizophrenia known for his "childlike" music.
Susan Te Kahurangi King (born 1951) is a New Zealand artist whose ability to speak declined by the age of four and stopped speaking altogether by age eight. King is an autistic savant who has methodically created an entire analogous world through extraordinary drawings using pen, graphite, colored pencil, crayon and ink. She drew prolifically through to the early 1990s and then without reason suddenly stopped. King renewed drawing in 2008 during filming of a documentary on her artwork.
Leonard Knight (1931–2014) created the Salvation Mountain, a covered hill art installation in the Colorado Desert that encompasses numerous murals and areas painted with Christian sayings and Bible verses.
George Paul Kornegay (1913–2014) created a large Christian visionary environment from found objects on a hill near his home in Brent, Alabama.
Norbert Kox (born 1945), formerly a hard-drinking and drugging member of the Outlaws biker gang, Norbert Kox began to produce a highly singular style of iconography sometime after his conversion to Christianity, and a long period of hermitage and study.
Paul Laffoley (1940–2015) an American artist, Laffoley's pieces are painted on large canvases and combine words and imagery to depict a spiritual architecture of explanation, tackling concepts like dimensionality, time travel through hacking relativity, connecting conceptual threads shared by philosophers through the millennia, and theories about the cosmic origins of mankind.
Maud Lewis (1903–1970) was a Canadian folk artist. Lewis painted bright scenes of rural Nova Scotian life on found objects, including boards, construction materials, etc.
Alexander Lobanov (1924–2003) was a withdrawn deaf Russian known for detailed and self-aggrandizing self-portraits: paintings, photographs and quilts, which usually include images of large guns.
Justo Gallego Martínez (born 1925)  is a Spanish former monk who has been erecting a cathedral-like building in the town of Mejorada del Campo, Spain, since 1961. The building has neither any planning permissions, nor has it the benediction of any church authority.
Helen Martins (1897–1976) transformed the house she inherited from her parents in Nieu-Bethesda, South Africa, into a fantastical environment decorated with crushed glass and cement sculptures. The house is known as The Owl House.
Tarcisio Merati (1934–1995), an Italian artist, was confined to a psychiatric hospital for most of his adult life during which time he produced a vast amount of drawings (several dream toys, bird on nest etc.), text and musical composition.
Markus Meurer (born 1959), a German artist, transforms found objects into mythic creations, hybrid creatures of animal, man and machine.
Ataa Oko (1919–2012), a Ghanaian artist who was one of the first builders of fantasy coffins and who became in collaboration with a social anthropologist, Regula Tschumi, a painter at the age of 85. He started to draw and paint his former fantasy coffins, but also religious ceremonies and spirits he pretended to see.
The Philadelphia Wireman, a creator of wire sculptures. Nothing is known of their identity and they are presumed deceased.
Martín Ramírez (1895–1963), a Mexican outsider artist who spent most of his adult life institutionalized in a California mental hospital (he had been diagnosed as paranoid schizophrenic). He developed an elaborate iconography featuring repeating shapes mixed with images of trains and Mexican folk figures.
Achilles Rizzoli (1896–1981) was employed as an architectural draftsman. He lived with his mother near San Francisco, California. After his death, a huge collection of elaborate drawings were discovered, many in the form of maps and architectural renderings that described a highly personal fantasy exposition, including portraits of his mother as a neo-baroque building.
Royal Robertson (1936–1997), a schizophrenic sign painter who received vivid, violent visions of spaceships, God, and the apocalypse, which he then translated into bright, colourful, comic-book like sketches, often including references to his wife's unfaithfulness.
Sam (Simon) Rodia (1875–1965) was an itinerant construction worker and untrained in the arts. Plagued by personal problems, he abandoned his family to ride the rails until he settled in Los Angeles and created the landmark Watts Towers.  Abandoning his monumental life's work, he returned to die with his family, among whom he was regarded as a bum, artist, crazy or a genius.
Eugenio Santoro (1920–2006) was an Italian sculptor and painter. He moved to Switzerland working as a laborer, then he began a brilliant career as a wood sculptor, carving life-size human and animals figures of great expressiveness from fruit trees, which he sometimes painted and coated with varnish.
John Schacht (1938–2009)  was a pre-Stonewall-generation gay artist from the American Midwest who created biomorphic, psychedelic-like abstract paintings, semi-representational erotic drawings and ritual-like altars and assemblages.
Friedrich Schröder Sonnenstern (1892–1982) was a German painter who achieved fame and notoriety in the 1950s and 60s for his scabrous, often erotic works.
Judith Scott (1943–2005) was born deaf and with Down syndrome. After being institutionalized for 35 years she attended Creative Growth Art Center (a center for artists with disabilities in Oakland, California) and went on to become an internationally renowned fiber art sculptor.
Richard Sharpe Shaver (1907–1975) produced photographs, paintings, drawings and writing connected to his unorthodox theories about the history of life on Earth. He believed that certain stones were actually image-filled "rock books" created by an ancient superior race, and that sadistic descendants of those ancients live inside the earth, using ancient "ray" machines to torment humankind.  His paintings, based on rock slices, often incorporate unusual materials such as soap flakes.
Charles Steffen (1927–1995), Chicago artist, made art while institutionalized.
Kea Tawana (born c. 1935), American sculptor who created the Ark, an 86-foot-long ship made from architectural salvage in a vacant lot in Newark, New Jersey.
Miroslav Tichý (1926–2011) was a photographer who took thousands of surreptitious pictures of women in his hometown of Kyjov in the Czech Republic, using homemade cameras constructed of cardboard tubes, tin cans and other at-hand materials.
Martin Thompson (born 1956) New Zealand artist self-diagnosed with Asperger syndrome. A mathematical savant, he hand draws obsessive fractal patterns on grid paper using art pens.
Harry Underwood (born 1969) is a self-taught American painter known for his use of stenciled images and literary elements atop wood panels, described by one critic as "a cocktail of realism, surrealism, and pop, of Edward Hopper meets Salvador Dali meets Andy Warhol". He grew up in a deeply religious household and was expelled from high school, later taking up painting while working as a laborer. Despite his expulsion from high school, his works contain complex literary elements, often weaving the painting into a full story in relatively few words.
Pierre Vuitton (1880–1962), French artist. After being severely wounded, both physically and psychologically, in World War I, Vuitton abandoned his previous life as the child of wealthy merchants. After several stays in sanitariums and mental hospitals, he moved to Paris in 1920. A user of morphine and alcohol, he lived as a casual laborer in poverty despite the occasional sale of his pictures. His first works were probably during the war years; later he developed "time-excesses" in which he reportedly spent several days painting without eating or sleeping. Increasingly, however, his deteriorating mental condition spoiled any binding relationship, so he spent most of his later life in mental hospitals or in nursing homes.
Willem van Genk (1927–2005) is the best known Dutch representative of outsider art. He was considered schizophrenic and autistic, and made drawings in view from above of stations and wirings, European cities, busses and trolleys, zeppelins and bombers. He also created 300 intricately decorated rain coats.
Wesley Willis (1963–2003), a schizophrenic musician and artist from Chicago, known for his prolific (and bizarre) musical recordings as well as his hundreds of colored ink-pen drawings of Chicago street-scapes. Many of his drawings appear as covers to his albums. Although Willis was poor and often dependent on the charity of friends for housing, his drawings now sell for thousands of dollars apiece.
Scottie Wilson (1928–1972) (born Louis Freeman), emigrated from Scotland to Canada and opened a second-hand clothes store, found fame when his casual doodlings were noted for their dream-like character.
Adolf Wölfli (1864–1930), a Swiss artist, was confined to a psychiatric hospital for most of his adult life during which time he produced a vast amount of drawings, text and musical composition. Wölfli was the first well-known "outsider artist", and he remains closely associated with the label.
Kiyoshi Yamashita (1922–1971) was a Japanese graphic artist who spent much of his life wandering as a vagabond through Japan. He has been considered an autistic savant.
Joseph Yoakum (1890–1972), an African-American artist who spent his last years producing a vast quantity of sinuous, surreal landscapes based on both real and imagined travels.
Stephen Wiltshire is a prodigious savant, capable of drawing the entire skyline of a city after a helicopter ride.
Anna Zemánková (1908–1986) was a self-taught Czech painter, draftsman and pastel artist. Her work was featured in a group show at London's Hayward Gallery in 1979, and eighteen of her pieces were shown at the Venice Biennale in 2013.
Lee Arthur Carter known as Viper (born 1971) is an American musician and rapper best known for producing 347 albums in one year and the single 'you'll cowards don't even smoke crack'. His style is lo-fi, chopped, slowed down, auto-tuned and often off-tempo.

text.quote: Museum with permanent & temporary exhibits of avant-garde pieces by self-taught, outsider artists.
trip: No doubts this is a place to go at least once, if you are in Lausanne. Just be ready to digest the information there and see another face of the world.

I was so fascinated by this mxuseum. Perfect place to visit alone, or with an introverted friend. ☺️ I spent 3-4 hours there, slowly walking around the exhibits, reading the artists' interesting bios, watching some that had 10 minute documentary-style videos, and absorbing the

The unexpected, the unusual, a home for outsider art before there was even such a category. Naive, regional and outsider artists convene in one outstanding collection of truly rarified art. Don't miss the tattoo collection (yes actual skin) dating from the 19th century. If

We were “blown away” with the variety of art in this museum. Very unusual and interesting. It was an uneasy feeling being around this art that was produced by people who were institutionalized. How does one respond?

Quite an interesting collection. Nice blurbs about the artists and their histories (English and French). Also an audio guide that can give you a little more about some of the pieces, but mostly they read what was on the written blurbs, though listening lets you walk around and

A display by those outside the mainstream, including some who were insane, not every display is accessible. Some are clearly using art to retreat, and the compulsiveness in their work is sad. Others just have a very different view of the world, from a fellow who draws train

The museum is newly opened (October 2019) after refurbishment and installation of a lift. Only the small top gallery is not accessible by wheelchair; it displays mainly decorated envelopes mailed to the curators. The museum has a fascinating permanent collection of artworks -

This was my first experience with Art Brut and I was utterly fascinated. The museum does a great job in explaining how the movement got started and showcases its original pieces very well. I highly recommend using the recording devices to hear the description of the artist as

The website informed and updated and corrected the re-opening date for completion of renovation - very appreciated!!! not to go in vain ----this shows consideration and attention to visitors --- so i was able to plan to go when it reopened. Very convenient to arrive by public
Very nice collection of art. Interesting the concept they had. Disturbed souls may well do amazing things!
It's unlike the other art museums that I have been. The Japanese collection was also very interesting. Since the artists are self taught, their artworks are very unique.

FYI - this museum is currently closed for construction from 4/29/2019 through, I believe, September 2019. This looks like a very interesting museum which is why I attempted to visit while in Lausanne recently but was disappointed to find out it is currently closed.
One of the best modern art museums I have had the pleasure to visit. Ten out of ten. I would recommend you make it a priority to visit when in Lausanne.
Fantastic place to visit on the weekend! The artwork is different and interesting even though it may not please everyone - its great! Make sure you go up to the attic.
Very well curated museum. Fascinating outsider art on 3 floors. Free first Saturday of the month. No cafe.

Hidden in a nicely renovated traditional Vaudois style building is this astonishing collection of art made by non artists. One wonders how the artists had the patience to make some of the most intricate works of art I've ever seen. Definitely worth a visit when you are in

Yes, it is a museum.. but it's a very unusual museum! It's really amazing how much art is hiding in the "sick minds", how we, who consider ourselves normal dare to call them... But it's enough to take your kids there to see that everything shown there is perfectly normal,

Regardless of the temporary exhibition going on, the museum's own collection will most probably fascinate or at least startle you given the true nature of this specific art in such a conservative country, note this in an hommage and not a demeaning judgement of Switzerland :)

Collection de l'Art Brut is a museum located a bit far from the center of Lausanne, a city of Switzerland. Here you can see some artworks of not-artist people. Some of the people were convicts, prisoners or crazy and here you can read about their lives and known a lot about

Surprising and impressive exhibition where the usual codes of art are overcome and becomes fully compulsive and obsessive. The artists, mainly people with psychic disease, are expressing within various supports in the depths of themselves and their works are exposed in with

I had almost skipped visiting this museum, but so glad I went. Its small and cute but spent 3 hours here..esp if you listen to the audio guide patiently. such wonderful works of art and marvellous experience. The ticket office accepts both euros and swiss francs.

A really interesting museum. I wasn't familiar with "Art Brut" before visiting it, and it was definitely worth it. Apart from elitist viewpoints like "art for the art", these works made from common people, people usually on the margins of society, people who were using their art
I loved this museum. It's a different experience. I've spent 2,5 hours getting absobed by these very special art forms and the artist's stories. Difficult to describe. I strongly recommend it.

This is a small gallery with lots to see. Some ‘gifted amateurs’ with difficult stories and some unusual art forms. For the keen gallery visitor it is a breath of fresh air: not a single big name, just a whole lot of talent.

We have visited the museum without knowing what ‘ Art Brut’ means . It is a nice collection but probably did not understand the meaning of most of the ‘disturbed ‘ pieces . There were very few pieces that I have really liked . Oh well !

Art brut is defined as art not being influenced by any school or education and is the fact of people either at the margin of the society or mentally disabled. The result is simply stunning and absolutely unorthodox. The second best museum in Lausanne after Musée Olympique.

The artists are convicts or psychopaths,human beings out of the society of the ordinary people. In any case their pictures are very strong and I insist that must vi- sit it eveybody who wants to know the influnce of the art and the strength of the human nature!

This museum owes its existence and opulence to Dubuffet. It is different from other museums due to the fact that all paintings, sculptures and other art, were created by non-professional artists. Basquiat, Banksy and others would have had their place there at some point in their
Very interesting and unusual museum as it exhibits art from people on the margins of the art. The museum is about a 20 minute walk from the center of town and the entrance fee is 10chf

This first acquaitance of mine with L' art brut was a revelation. It uncovered another aspect of art I was not aware of. Art may be beautiful, ugly, sophisticated, naive, eventive, liberating, healing and many more. Not only for those who create art but for those who are

Very interesting museum which exhibits "Outsider Art." If you don't have a background in art history, no worries. Explanations in French and English explain what it is and give insight into individual artists.

The museum is about a 20 minute walk from the center of town. It's an interesting and unusual place as it exhibits art from folks on the margins of the art world (residents or psychiatric hospitals, prisoners, etc.). Depending on your interest, a 1 hour visit is enough for a
Always very interesting and mentally stimulating "outsider art". Expands our boundarys of what is "normal"

We went today to this museum with our two teenage daughters (14 and 16). We were all impressed. The art (Art Brut) is made by self-taught people who often live on the margins of society (for instance residents of psychiatric hospitals, prisoners or eccentrics). The art crawls

If you are in Lausanne Collection de l'Art Brut is a must see exhibition. It's quite tourist-friendly because they have a written guide in English (actually the alphabetically arranged biographies of the creators) and also an English-speaking audio guide. Furthermore, if you

This is a fascinating collection of unusual art. We spent a good hour and a half or more here - unusual for us. The museum offers audio guides in several languages but French, English and German speaking folks can do without, since all of the displays are signed in those

During my stay at the Madison d’ Ecrivains in Lavigny on one of the rainy days that bring the slow clouds from Lake Geneva, we decided to take the train up to Lausanne to go to the Musee De l’Art Brut. It was a life changing, as well as enriching experience. I was lucky to
Not like any other museum Nothing classically beautiful Brut Brut Brut Wonderful to see art thru original eyes
That was an excellent visit. The traditionnal expo as well the temporary were very intresting, beautiful, intriguing. I recommend highly

Dubuffet was the initiator of this remarkable museum. If you don't know what art brut means, go on wikipedia. Once visited, you'll never ask again and will come back regularly. It is never crowded and gives you time to appreciate a non-classical form of art.

Art museums around the world have become repositories of the classics that created our cultural identity and finding the Collection de l'Art Brut is such a marvel. I love this museum for over 40 years and the collection is so unique that you will be both astonished and taken

This is a very different — and very special art museum in Lausanne, located in Beaulieu, Lausanne. It’s a bit of a schlep to get there as it’s about half an hour’s walk north from Lausanne central train station, but totally worth the detour to visit. This art gallery is all

It is one of my most favourite muséums and not only in Lausanne, but in general. The collection is great, very rich. Créations are amazing, very touching. There is really a special energy at this place. Highly recommend to visit!
I was a bit reluctant to visit, expecting much darker experience. Lovingly collected, well displayed.
Unique museum with a very genuine and original approach to art. Many authors with little education and not influenced by the society. Worth visiting it.

I visited this gallery and was simply stunned at the power and strength of the work. It told stories of human resilience and sorrow. Love and loss and a quest for identity and acceptance. It supports that amazing work of marginalized and segregated groups and shows the healing

I have been to a lot of art galleries but this is a one off. The stories told through the artists vision reveals total heart and soul. So many different experiences that made these artists want to create. Apart from the work being strikingly wonderful, it really inspired me to
So glad i went here, first time I went it was closed but went back at opening time. The are works are from amazing creative minds. Really worth going
I've never seen anything like this before. My wife is an artist and this was like a heaven on earth for her... It's something special which you can't see everywhere.
Really unique museum on the "art brut" concept developed by Dubuffet... always magical to visit , again and again

I came on Rick Steves recommendation and was glad I did, its worth the visit, as you do see art in a different form. The artists are from societies fringe with unfortunate childhood stories, criminal backgrounds, mental health challenges. Their artwork benefited both them and

I really liked the museum, I found the stories interesting and the artwork moving. However my companion did not like it at all: he found most not very pretty and did not feel like reading the descriptions.

The only day it rained while we were in Lausanne, so my husband and I hopped on a bus and off we went to this famous museum of outsider art. What a weird and wonderful place! The stories alone are worth going for, and the pieces on display were interesting, disturbing, and

If you can set aside many of the lessons you have learned about "art" and just go into this exhibition with an inquiring and interested mind then you will not be disappointed. Much of the art was at the end of the 19th century or beginning of the 20th. Many of the artists had

Well worth your time to visit this gem of an art museum. The art has been done by non-professionally trained artists..who have produced this beautiful and interesting pieces of art because they 'had to'. They didn't create their work for commercial sales but because this was

This museum is full of surprises. Perhaps the best known of the artists is Aloïse (from Lausanne) but there are over 140 artists from at least 10 countries including 10 artists from the United States. You can spend many hours contemplating the raw intensity of the artistic

Just visited this great little museum. It's in a beautiful old building, that's been totally gutted on the inside. The artists are all marginalized people, who had terrible upbringing and many ended up in mental institutions , so it's quit different. Many of the works are

It's a crazy place. Litteraly and figuratively. Artists with psychic disabilities from all around the world and from different times. You have to go there. Then again, beware, it takes a lot of time, it's bigger than it seems and there's a lot of content. And I must admit I was

Experience different thinking and view art from a different lens and angle. Be open and tolerant !! This place is possibly unique in Europe, do not miss it and confront yourself to a different thinking and art pattern.
Vivid presentation of emotions, states of depression, mental disorders. It's definitely worth visiting to see how those people express their internal fights through art.
The Collection de l'Art Brut is a gem of a place featuring the works of several off-beat artists including the wonderful Henry Darger and James Edward Deeds. Well presented. A compelling place.
A bit out of the way but worth the wander up the hill. My favourite collection in Lausanne. Not muc to recomend the cafe next door but the garden is decent place in the summer for a beer.
Unique art museum, beautiful pieces, fabulous life stories. One needs almost 2 visits as a lot to take in.Close to Beaulieu, no parking so easiest by bus.

I am so glad I spent an afternoon at the museum. I was amazed by the collection of pieces made by, not trained artists, but by people with amazing life stories. Don't miss this if you are in the region.
A unique collection for the first museum of this kind. Great discovery and an obligatory visit when you are in the region!

I did not know what to expect when I want to see this Museum. To my surprise, it touched me on many ways. I love the real art that comes from hart and not worrying about people making comments on it! The stories behind it will touch you. Easy access by bus and you need about 2

This is not your classic art museum but rather a fringe exhibition which is thought provoking and moving. It is a personal journey for each person whose work is exhibited and we found it fascinating. It is a very powerful form of expression. Do not miss it!
A very interesting exhibition of the works of the people who never planned to be an artist. The stories... tragic, crazy, magical... Plus professional preparation of the exhibition.
I have been to this museum many times now and every time i discover something new. The stories behind every item are fascinating! I recommend everyone to go there at least once!

very impressive collection, including an important donation made in 1971 by Jean Dubuffet to the city of Lausanne. Now we could see in rather good condition a little part, eventually the best parts of works out of collection of more than 60.000 pieces maid by mentally ill

...then visit this one. The art presented there is unique, fascinating and most of all touching. Pro tip: Take the trolleybus from the train station and, after your visit, walk back (mostly downhill) through the pedestrian streets of the city centre.
Very diversified display, unusual pieces of art, high quality and above all, amazing personal stories. Not a very big place but of high intensity. A must experience!

If you are visiting or living in Lausanne, take your chance to visit this uncommon museum located not far from the city center (by bus). It features a collection of art pieces from unconventional artists not following any artistic movement.

You can not come to Lausanne without visiting it. Rare and Fabulous Collection. The Art Brut gives voice to artists who are/were self-taught and very often deprived of liberty (psychiatric hospitals) You will feelchanged after seing it
This is a great collection of great artists, often not known.You can explore different collections and lives of the authors. This experience leaves many touched.
I absolutely loved this art collection! It was interesting to read the stories of the artists alongside their work. If you enjoy art, modern art or psychology, don't miss this!
A strange and strong experience: paintings and other artwork created by artists on the fringe of schizophrenia. Fascinating.
There is nothing like this collection in the world. Special and impressive. Culture at top level!!!!
entering this place is an experience, not a vitsit to a museum. It lets you think further and putting those pièces of art to the public is not only courageous, it is a necessity. thanks
Beautiful place and wonderful expositions. The time you'll spend there will enrich your life. Strongly suggested.

Collection de l'Art Brut in Lausanne. One of the best museum that I ve ever seen. In this museum , you can join numerous paintings ans statues made from more than 400 artists and every piece is a Masterpiece. Every artwork is creative and interesting but in order to understand

The artwork is creative and diverse but make sure you read each short bios about what the artist endured to produce the work. Many suffered from mental disorders and dealt with traumas and it is evident in what is produced. You may not come out laughing but you'll come out the

This art collection comes from people suffering from psychological or withdrawal issues. It is inspired from true life events and feelings and each piece of art is unique. The museum is full of diverse types of art and feelings. A must-see!

The term Art Brut was coined by the French artist, Jean Dubuffet (1901-1985). He, as well the CoBrA artist of the same time, thought that creativity was a human trait best found in those who were not “trammeled” by conventions and art training. So he looked to children, the

This collection shows that "Art" doesn't know boundaries. If you go with children, they also will be inspired by the primal approach of the artists, even if some works may not be suitable for small children. The only negative point is, in my view, the very dark interieur.
collections are well displayed and the museum is not too small not too big so its very plaisant to visit
A simple museum of uncategorized art. The art works are unbelievably emotional and I cannot get enough of going there. I also recommend this place to any of my friends coming to town.

This museum never ceases to impress me. The stories behind the pieces of art are touching, sad and sometimes shocking. It's shown me that sometimes from the darkest depths may come forth the most amazing works of art. I see this museum as a tribute to the mystery and beauty of
stunning pieces of art, well documented, big enough to spend a couple of hours if you want to dive yourself into the Art Brut world

It is a must see if you are in Lausanne. A wonderful collection of outsider art, excellent presented. Exiting artist with interesting biographies, soothing in a so cold "art-world", where it gets only for prices and commerce. Very interesting objects. My personal highlight of

The principal collection of artwork, some of which is done in maticulous detail impresses, the sad element is discovered, when you learn that a number of the artists suffered from mental health issues, or disabilities that would set them at odds with the norm. So; the collection

A local recommended this gallery. Not large but moving & fascinating. All the artists have overcome major challenges (Downs Syndrome, illiteracy, mental illness) to produce works that belie any disadvantage.In fact, you could say that disadvantage has been turned around to offer

This Collection has been the nicest and best surprise of my stay in Lausanne. The large number of arts and the quality of the different artists was such a surprise. I was not expecting that much of emotions. The display emphasizes the pieces of arts. Can be made in an hour and

Established to collect art works of people with mental challenges, the art is stupendous. Three floors of wall covered art will let you be amazed what art can truly mean. Both unsettling and provocative, most pieces will make you think differently about what art can be. The

Love love love this museum. Several floors of artworks covering ceramics, Clay , embroidery, drawing and painting and more. The potted history beside each piece gives you an insight into the sometimes very traumatic story behind the artist. Many of the artists suffer from

We went on the first Saturday of the month which is always free of charge. This is a fascinating collection and every room holds displays which are linked by the common theme of a mental instability or illness which has inspired some amazing and fascinating images and art work.
Fine line between genius and insanity but on the other hand I'm not sure many of these artists would be confused with Picasso.
Really interesting concept of a museum. Does depend on what is on show, as to whether you like it all. But the stories of each person, by their art is really cool.

This museum is highly rated on TA for a great reason. This is a seriously curated museum of art by non traditional artists for art lovers and, as in my case the husbands that are less interested, but tolerate their spouses taste in the arts. Really beautiful images and sculpture

If you don't know what "art brute" is, you'll be surprised to discover so many different creations that have a unique inspiration. Each piece of art is conceived by the artist without any knowledge of mainstream art techniques. It is solely the vision of the artist that gives

It's a really nice collection, and it's set up differently every year depending on the theme of the temporary exposition they organize. You can find there some really beautiful and original drawings and paintings, I like most the ones dealing with details and/or with serial

This wonderful museum exhibits the works of artists who have various types of mental handicaps and have been interned in asylums. Much of the collection is possible thanks to the work of artist Jean Dubuffet. I can't say enough about the fascinating nature of this art and one
Europe is rich in terms of its art collection. This museum however stands out as it is artwork from people who are not a part of mainstream society (prisoners, patients, loners etc.). Awesome work!

Much better than expected for a small city. Eclectic mix of lesser known artists using a multitude of mediums and subjects. Well lit, organized and labeled. Four floors with the right amount of art. I am still amazed at the artists stories.

I've been here many times to bring friends visiting from abroad. It has an amazing collection and very interesting exhibitions every time I visit. In my opinion it's one of the most interesting things to see in Lausanne.

What an incredible concept for an art museum! After traveling through Europe for almost two months, this collection was a breath of fresh air and an important experience on its own. I really hope this concept of giving a voice to those neglected on the fringe through displaying
Amazing place, not only by the exhibits but the place is also a very interesting old house. The exhibits linger a long time in your mind, just open your eyes and your heart.

What a surprising and touching collection this is! Truly nothing else compares. Be sure to get to all the floors, and be prepared to check bags in the lockers on the ground floor. Not cheap--nothing in Switzerland is cheap--but well worth it.

You need an open mind and open heart to see, observe, and appreciate the art here - take your time, but make it to the top floor to see the current exhibit. It is a powerful museum experience, that delves into the minds and uncovers the treasures of tormented, but expressive
A collection of art done by people usually not considered artists. Some works are truly amazing and some not so good. A lot of character is in the stories of the people behind the art.
Very unique collection and some truly amazing pieces of art work, all carefully curated. Must visit in Lausanne! No. 2 bus will take you right there.

A pretty small, however, well-curated museum which is close to the city center. It is a place for pieces of art-work that only exist once, many of them done by human beings who were locked away in mental institutions. Very impressive and expressive, you can bring your kids along

If you are visiting Lausanne, I highly recommend you to visit this museum unique in its kind. At least once a year, I visit its permanent and changing exhibitions in company of my family, with friends or alone. I am always surprised, inspired and profoundly moved by the
I have lived in Lausanne for 2 years now. This museum remains the best I've ever visited in the Region. Alternative, original, stunning, mind-blowing. Recommended for all ages, to all sort of people.

This museum is a one-off. It makes you look at things differently and is beautifully exhibited. It shows the inside workings of some very strange minds and even if you don't like the art (some of which is disturbing) it is a and unique experience.
Near the center of lausanne, really easy to go there, really interesting, a lot of thing to see and to do, perfect for family, prices are good ! I liked it !

Every first saturday of the month, it is free. I was already impressed by the stories placed outside of the museum. How interesting things people can build by them selves; some were very creative and others were just crazy. And that is being realized by our culture. Anyways,

Any visit to Lausanne will be remiss without a visit to the unassuming 2-story building of the Collection de l'Art Brut. It hosts one of the most amazing collection of genuine art, unspoiled by intellectualism and pretentiousness.

This exhibition is an interesting collection of art pieces produced by persons who have mental disorders and intellectual impairments. I found my visit to be a very moving and thought provoking experience.
Really like this place, its a bit weird, but I guess to be expected! well worth a visit to look at art by the criminally insane.

If there is one reason to visit Lausanne, this should be it. In a very well displayed collection you can see modern, mostly abstract art from painters and sculptors you do NOT know, which helps make it exciting. The descriptions of the artists (in English as well as in French
I have never seen such a collection! Beautiful and strange too! Made us think about the connections that make up the human mind.
One of the most fascinating museums I've visited! Art from the minds of those considered mentally ill? Yes! I found the pieces created by those with OCD the most interesting.
Very interesting museum. Enjoyed the Guy Brunet collection especially Nice surprise in Lausanne. Good for rainy days

Was very interesting! Larger than it looks from the outside with 4 floors. Exhibits ranged from untrained, rustic artists to classically trained artists that had emotional or psychological problems. Art ranged from drawings and paintings to rustic clockwork type pieces and

This museum is absolutely fantastic. You don't have to be an art fan or an expert to go there. The stories behing the paintings/carving will not leave you indifferent. Many of the artists are/were mentally ill and art was their only way to communicate. Some artwork are truly

This is a small museum with a collection of folk art, nearly all created by people on the margins of society (i.e. incarcerated or institutionalized). Some of the artwork appeared to be very personal and I was concerned that the creator might not have given consent or the
Suitable for kids who will enjoy the quirky displays and have fun answering the quiz. Interesting for adults too of course!
very nice expositions! some permanent some stay just for short period. unusual art amazing to contemplate and very interesting stories to read

My uncle suggested this museum, and he was right to do so! I loved the artwork as well as the stories the signs told about the artists (also in English). With almost every artist I got the funny feeling that the longer I looked at his/her work, the more there was to see, while

It's a very unusual, different from any other art museum. The collection is huge, consists of many artworks on several floors. I visited it during free Saturday (first Saturday of the month). Lots of artist vere mentally ill or had a very hard life, very often sad family

If you like to think out of the box, this is the place for you. A museum without pretensions that gives visibility to "humble great artist", out of the art business. Art as a way to liberate the spirit, no matter what comes out. I enjoyed it so much!

This is a unique collection of artworks by those artists who were untrained and who experienced challenging lives, often shaped by mental illness and solitude. This collection offers a fascinating insight into the creative minds of these special artists who work in a broad range
For those wanting to see something out-of-the-irdinary, this is the plae to find it. The museum is small, but exhibits high quality art.
It is not expensive and it's worth the trip. We saw beautifull paintings and it is fairly easy to reach by bus
The art at L'Art Brut is strange and awesome. It is one of the best museums in Lausanne and I always make a point of visiting it when I am in town.

It's an incredible museum. We are used to intellectualize art , take it in with our esthetically developed senses ..instead , what you see in that Museum (de l'art bruit) is unexpected , raw, honest conversation of the artist with him/herself. They don't need to impress, they

Art Brut tends to be the number one recommended art museum for visitors in Lausanne, although it is located on the outskirts of town. Lausanne is built into the side of a pretty steep hill, so getting to the city sites requires some leg strength, but every step up allows a
It's quite interesting to learn about their stories, backgrounds & the reasons of creating those art pieces.

Reading the personal history (in French & English) about each artist gave fascinating insight to their work. The collection is small and well curated. If you like museums, and I do, this is a must see in Lausanne.

Great small musuem focused on art brut. The personal stories of the artists were fascinating and much of the art was great as well. But if this style of art isn't your thing, you'll probably be disappointed.

I say it's an absolute must because I haven't come across anything quite like this- in terms of the unique concept and the fantastic quality of artworks. The collection is beautiful and the stories accompanying each artist truly enhances your experience. Take 2.5 hours to

Well, the Trip Advisor worldwide community is to be admired because it was only because of TA that we discovered this remarkable collection. It is difficult to describe but the unique exhibition of artwork in many different media created by disturbed minds is hugely powerful.

I went with my whole family at this museum (three generations) and this was really pleasant for everyone. The collection and the building is great. It is of course very different from other museum because the collection are simply unique. The presentation is great and it is

We stumbled on this place by searching, where-else, TripAdvisor. It sounded very interesting and indeed it was. Although when you read the description one might think this was going to be cool and creepy but really it is more like a fine collection of folk art. There are very

This museum exposes works of people afflicted with psychotic disorders. Their artistic output surpasses often the level of contemporary painters who make heavy money of their art. You come across many people who became orphans at an early age and were apparently pathologically

This must be one of the most original museums in Europe, if not in the world. None of the "artists" is a commonly known painter. Most of the exhibits stem from patients in psychiatric institutions. Very intertesting experience; very colorfull.

If you're interested in Art Brut or if you never heard about it, this is a very intersting museum. A lot of questions about what is Art, who is an artist? If you can take the guide tour, it's really great to know the story behind the people.

A great museum to visit. All artists have psychiatric difficulties and their emotions and/or sentiments are very strong. Your will leave "la collection de l'art brut" with a lot of questions concerning art but also about people.
Great place to visit, wonderful pieces of art that also let you think about what's considered "normal" and "abnormal" in our society. Very recommended!

Loved this place; it was so interesting to get a glimpse into the minds of individuals who went through e.g prison, psychiatric institution or elongated solitude and the way they expressed themselves through art or sculpture. The museum was well set out and had a great variety

I found out about this art gallery from TripAdvisor and since it was raining it was perfect. I loved the idea of the gallery which exhibits art pieces from unknown artists, mental patients, prisoners and so on, with a story about the artist and their lives. There are a lot of

If you plan on spending time inside at all on your trip to Switzerland, take the time to visit this museum. It's tucked away in a quiet part of town, and the building is quite camouflaged as well. Inside the doors though, you enter a new world - one created by the people that
a fascinating trip into the mind of human beings, and art's hiding places. loved the incredible variety, some images can be quite troubling, so I would not go with very young children

The background of the artists provides very interesting context to the art which is displayed in many forms and scales. As commented, some art is rather dark and disturbing, other work is delightfully eccentric, and plenty is quite conventional and brilliantly executed in spite

The basics first - the entry fee is fairly low cost, the woman who spoke to us on the tills spoke perfect english, all bags have to be put in lockers before you enter the exhibit (1CHF which you get back) and no photography is allowed. Nearest bus stop is Beaulieu or

Collection of art from the institutionalized and incarcerated. Most of the artists represented here had lives that none of us would envy, and yet each of them managed to leave something behind that could help all of us understand the human condition just a little bit better. Do

Examples: Little Billy grew up in Hungary and tried to burn down his house 4 times by the age of 12 and was committed to a mental institution. He escaped at age 25 and lived undiscovered for 20 years in the basement of a castle. His dead body was discovered along with 3000
It is not the art you used to see in the museums, this is something beyond your normal understanding. All the stories and exhibits are truly shocking.

I am not a big museum enthusiast, but this place shook me and kept me thinking about its exhibits and stories for a long time after I left. Reading the stories behind the exhibits gives a good perspective about the world that we are living in.
If you have the time, this is a worthwhile stop. Very interesting art from some very talented people (but with mental illnesses or dire situations).
An art experience not to be missed in this lifetime of original encounters to refresh the creative soul. So down to earth and refreshing.
Most of the literature says its prisoner art, but in fact it is art by self taught artists of all kinds a unique collection and really worth seeing.
This is the largest and most beautiful collection of Art Brut. There is always a special exhibit on, always interesting and the regular collection is amazing.

text.wiki:
The Palais de Rumine is a late 19th-century building in Florentine Renaissance style in Lausanne, Switzerland.


== History ==

On his death, Gabriel de Rumine, son of Russian nobility, left the city of Lausanne 1.5 million Swiss Francs to erect a building for the use of the public.
Building began in 1892 according to the design of the Lyonnais architect Gaspard André. The Palais was inaugurated on the 3 November 1902, although building work continued until 1904.
On 24 July 1923, the Treaty of Lausanne was signed in Palais de RumineIt housed facilities such as the library of the University of Lausanne, and scientific and artistic collections belonging to the Canton of Vaud.
In the 1980s, the university moved to its current location by Lake Geneva due to lack of space, and the Palais was restructured.


== Current use ==
The building currently hosts one of the three sites of the Cantonal and University Library of Lausanne. Additionally, it contains the following museums:

Musée cantonal des beaux-arts (Cantonal Museum of Fine Arts)
Musée cantonal d'archéologie et d'histoire (Cantonal Museum of Archeology and History)
Musée monétaire cantonal (Cantonal Museum of Money)
Musée cantonal de géologie (Cantonal Museum of Geology)
Musée cantonal de zoologie (Cantonal Museum of Zoology)


== Gallery ==

		
		
		
		
		


== See also ==

University of Lausanne


== Notes and references ==

text.wiki:
The Esplanade of Montbenon (French: Esplanade de Montbenon) is an area of the city of Lausanne (Switzerland). It is located in the centre of the city, to the south of Flon.


== Casino de Montbenon ==
The Casino de Montbenon was built in 1908. It hosted the headquarters of the International Olympic Committee from 1915 to 1922.
The Casino de Montbenon currently hosts the Swiss Film Archive, assembly halls and a restaurant (the Brasserie de Montbenon). The building contains the Cinématographe that serves as a movie theater for the Swiss Film Archive, the multi-use concert hall and movie theater Salle Paderewski as well as the Salle des fêtes, a large multi-use space that can host different kinds of events. Apart from the activities of the Swiss Film Archive, the Casino de Montbenon also hosts punctual events such as the Lausanne Underground Film and Music Festival, the jazz festival Jazz Onze+ and the film festival Cinémas d'Afrique amongst others.


== Palais de justice ==
The Palais de justice de Montbenon ("Montbenon Law Courts") was built between 1881 and 1886 to host the Federal Supreme Court of Switzerland. In the 1920s, the Federal Supreme Court moved to the Parc de Mon Repos and the building currently hosts the Tribunal d'arrondissement de Lausanne.
