=== Religion ===
From the Reformation in the 16th century, the city was mostly Protestant until the late 20th century, when it received substantial immigration, particularly from largely Catholic countries. Catholics now form a plurality of the city's population.
From the 2000 census, 47,225 people (37.8% of the population) were Roman Catholic, while 33,993 (27.2%) belonged to the Swiss Reformed Church. Of the rest of the population, there were 2,698 members of an Orthodox church (2.16%), there were 65 individuals (0.05%) who belonged to the Christian Catholic Church, and there were 4,437 individuals (3.55%) who belonged to another Christian church. There were 849 individuals (0.68%) who were Jewish, and 7,501 (6.00%) who were Muslim. There were 452 individuals who were Buddhist, 772 individuals who were Hindu and 343 individuals who belonged to another church. 21,080 (16.88%) belonged to no church, were agnostic or atheist, and 7,590 individuals (6.08%) did not answer the question.


=== Crime ===

In 2014 the crime rate, of crimes listed in the Swiss Criminal Code, in Lausanne was 167.3 per thousand residents. During the same period, the rate of drug crimes was 49.5 per thousand residents, and the rate of violations of immigration, visa and work permit laws was 21 per thousand residents.


== Transport ==

Lausanne is served by an extensive network of local, national and international public transport. National and international passenger trains of the Swiss Federal Railways depart from Lausanne railway station, which is also the hub of the Réseau Express Vaudois commuter rail system, and a stop on the city's metro. The metro and local buses are operated by Transports publics de la région lausannoise (TL), with many routes run using trolleybuses. Additional commuter trains are run by the Lausanne–Echallens–Bercher railway (LEB) from Lausanne-Flon station. Ships across Lake Geneva are provided by the Compagnie Générale de Navigation sur le lac Léman (CGN).
Lausanne became the first city in Switzerland to have a rubber-tyred metro system, with the m2 Line which opened in October 2008. The rolling stock is a shorter version of the one used on Paris Métro Line 14. Further expansion of the system is planned, as is the re-introduction of trams.Lausanne is connected to the A1 motorway on its west side (Geneva – Zürich axis) and to the A9 on its north and east side (for transit with Italy and France); the interchange between these two motorways is on the north-west side of the city.
Lausanne Airport is located at Blécherette, and also houses a Boeing 737 Simulator. The city is also directly linked by train to the Geneva International Airport, four times an hour, in 42min.


== Economy ==

As of  2010, Lausanne had an unemployment rate of 8%. As of 2008, there were 114 people employed in the primary economic sector and about 25 businesses involved in this sector. 6,348 people were employed in the secondary sector and there were 698 businesses in this sector. 83,157 people were employed in the tertiary sector, with 6,501 businesses in this sector.There were 59,599 residents of the municipality who were employed in some capacity, of which females made up 47.4% of the workforce. In 2008 the total number of full-time equivalent jobs was 75,041. The number of jobs in the primary sector was 93, of which 56 were in agriculture, 34 were in forestry or lumber production and 3 were in fishing or fisheries. The number of jobs in the secondary sector was 6,057 of which 1,515 or (25.0%) were in manufacturing, 24 or (0.4%) were in mining and 3,721 (61.4%) were in construction. The number of jobs in the tertiary sector was 68,891. In the tertiary sector; 8,520 or 12.4% were in wholesale or retail sales or the repair of motor vehicles, 2,955 or 4.3% were in the movement and storage of goods, 4,345 or 6.3% were in a hotel or restaurant, 4,671 or 6.8% were in the information industry, 6,729 or 9.8% were the insurance or financial industry, 8,213 or 11.9% were technical professionals or scientists, 5,756 or 8.4% were in education and 14,312 or 20.8% were in health care.In 2000, there were 55,789 workers who commuted into the municipality and 19,082 workers who commuted away. The municipality is a net importer of workers, with about 2.9 workers entering the municipality for every one leaving. About 1.9% of the workforce coming into Lausanne are coming from outside Switzerland, while 0.1% of the locals commute out of Switzerland for work. Of the working population, 40.9% used public transportation to get to work, and 35.1% used a private car.
Philip Morris International, a tobacco company, has its international headquarters in Lausanne.
Tetra Laval, a multinational packaging corporation, has its international headquarters in Lausanne.
Nespresso, an operating unit of the Nestlé Group, based in Lausanne.
Logitech, the computer peripherals company has its headquarters in Lausanne.


== Education ==

In Lausanne about 40,118 or (32.1%) of the population have completed non-mandatory upper secondary education, and 22,934 or (18.4%) have completed additional higher education (either university or a Fachhochschule). Of the 22,934 who completed tertiary schooling, 38.7% were Swiss men, 31.3% were Swiss women, 17.1% were non-Swiss men and 12.9% were non-Swiss women.In the 2009/2010 school year there were a total of 12,244 students in the Lausanne school district. In the Vaud cantonal school system, two years of non-obligatory pre-school are provided by the political districts. During the school year, the political district provided pre-school care for a total of 2,648 children of which 1,947 children (73.5%) received subsidized pre-school care. The canton's primary school program requires students to attend for four years. There were 6,601 students in the municipal primary school program. The obligatory lower secondary school program lasts for six years and there were 5,244 students in those schools. There were also 399 students who were home schooled or attended another non-traditional school.Lausanne is home to a number of museums including; the Collection de l'art brut, the Espace Arlaud, the Fondation de l'Hermitage, the Musée cantonal d'archéologie et d'histoire, the Musée cantonal de géologie, the Musée cantonal de zoologie, the Cantonal Museum of Fine Arts, the Museum of Contemporary Design and Applied Arts, the Musée de l'Élysée and the Musée historique de Lausanne. In 2009 the Collection de l'art brut was visited by 27,028 visitors (the average in previous years was 33,356). The Espace Arlaud was visited by 9,222 visitors (the average in previous years was 14,206). The Fondation de l'Hermitage was visited by 89,175 visitors (the average in previous years was 74,839). The Musée cantonal d'archéologie et d'histoire was visited by 14,841 visitors (the average in previous years was 15,775). The Musée cantonal de zoologie was visited by 30,794 visitors (the average in previous years was 30,392). The Musée cantonal de géologie was visited by 28,299 visitors (the average in previous years was 24,248). The Cantonal Museum of Fine Arts was visited by 26,456 visitors (the average in previous years was 26,384). The Museum of Contemporary Design and Applied Arts was visited by 28,554 visitors (the average in previous years was 22,879). The Musée de l'Élysée was visited by 36,775 visitors (the average in previous years was 37,757). The Musée historique de Lausanne was visited by 23,116 visitors (the average in previous years was 22,851).As of 2000, there were 12,147 students in Lausanne who came from another municipality, while 2,258 residents attended schools outside the municipality.


=== Libraries ===
Lausanne is home to eight large libraries or collections of libraries. These libraries include: Cantonal and University Library of Lausanne, the library of the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Lausanne (EPFL), the libraries of the Réseau EPFL, the Bibliothèque municipale de Lausanne, the Haute école de travail social et de la santé (EESP), the HECV Santé, the Haute école de la santé La Source and the École cantonale d'art de Lausanne (ECAL). There was a combined total (as of 2008) of 3,496,260 books or other media in the libraries, and in the same year a total of 1,650,534 items were loaned out.

=== Heritage sites of national significance ===
There are 46 buildings or sites that are listed as Swiss heritage site of national significance. Additionally, the entire old city of Lausanne and the Vernand-Dessus region are listed in the Inventory of Swiss Heritage Sites.
Religious Buildings: Notre-Dame Cathedral, Swiss Reformed Church of Saint-François, Swiss Reformed Church of Saint-Laurent and the Synagogue at Avenue de Florimont.
Civic Structures: Former Hôpital at Rue Mercerie 24, Former Federal Tribunal, the Former Académie at Rue Cité-Devant 7, Casino de Montbenon, St-Maire Castle, Bois-de-Vaux Cemetery, Fondation de l’Hermitage and House de maître, Railway station, Beau-Rivage Palace, City Hall, Hôtel des Postes, Administration Building of André & Cie. S.A., Administration Building of the Vaudoise Assurances, Apartment and Office Building at Rue du Grand-Chêne 8, Les Bains de Bellerive, l’Estérel House, House at Chemin de Chandolin 4, the Mon-Repos estate at Parc de Mon-Repos, Olympic Museum and Archives of the International Olympic Committee, the vessels of the CGN (La Suisse (1910), Savoie (1914), Simplon (1920), Rhône (1927)), Pont Chauderon, the Vernand-Dessus rural site, Site de l’Expo 64 avec Théatre de Vidy, the Tour Bel-Air and the University Hospital of Lausanne (CHUV).
Museums and Libraries: Former Residence of the Bishop of Lausanne which is now the Lausanne Museum of History, Bibliothèque des cèdres (former Bibliothèque des pasteurs), Beaulieu Castle and the Collection de l'art brut, Fondation Toms Pauli Collection de tapisseries and d’art textile, Galeries Saint-François, Musée de l'Élysée, Museum of Contemporary Design and Applied Arts (MUDAC), Cantonal Botanical Museum and Gardens, the Roman Museum, the Palais de Rumine with the Musée cantonal de géologie, Cantonal Museum of Zoology, Cantonal Museum of Fine Arts, Musée monétaire cantonal de Lausanne (Cabinet des médailles) and Musée cantonal d'archéologie et d'histoire.
Archives: Archives of the Banque Vaudoise, Archives of the City of Lausanne, Archives of Énergie Ouest Suisse (EOS), the Radio Suisse Romande archives and the Federal Supreme Court of Switzerland with archives.
Archeological sites: The Roman era/medieval hill-top city and the prehistoric settlement and Roman era Vicus of Vidy (Lousanna).
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		


=== Culture ===

The Orchestre de chambre de Lausanne, the Lausanne Opera and the Ensemble vocal de Lausanne provide a diverse and rich musical life. The latter has been under the direction of Michel Corboz for many years.
In January, the Prix de Lausanne, a famous dance competition, takes place at the Palais de Beaulieu (the biggest theatre in Switzerland) over a one-week period. The event attracts dancers and some of the big names in dance from all over the world.
The Swiss Film Archive is based in Lausanne and the city hosts film festivals such as the Festival cinémas d'Afrique and the Lausanne Underground Film and Music Festival. In addition to modern cinemas, the "Capitole" (in activity since 1929) is the biggest cinema in Switzerland (currently 867 seats).The town hosted the Eurovision Song Contest 1989. Each July, the Festival de la cité is held in the old part of town. Other music festivals include the Bach Festival, the Festival et concours Bach de Lausanne, which follows the Nuit de musées (museums' night) in the fall season.
Lausanne is also the home of the Béjart Ballet.

== Sports ==

Lausanne is home to the IOC, with water sports available on the nearby lake and mountaineering in the nearby mountains. Cycling is also a common pastime, with the vineyards in the surrounding hills providing extensive views and challenging routes. There is an annual Track and field meeting (Athletissima), road running through the city (the 20 km (12 mi) of Lausanne), the Tour de Romandie road cycling race, Marathon of Lausanne and triathlon competition, among other sports events. The two most important sports are ice hockey and football. Lausanne will host the 2020 Winter Youth Olympics and the 2020 IIHF World Championship.

text.wiki:
The SL-Rasch GmbH Special and Lightweight Structures, based in Stuttgart, Germany, specializes in special buildings and lightweight structures integrating architecture and engineering. The company was founded by Mahmoud Bodo Rasch.
SL-Rasch has executed projects for the holy cities Mekka and Medina, such as the Convertible Umbrellas and Sliding Domes for the Extension of the Prophet's Mosque in Medina the Tent City in Mina, and the tower top of the Makkah Clock Tower.
In 1980 Mahmoud Bodo Rasch founded the architecture firm Rasch and Associates and then, in 1991, the special and lightweight construction firm SL GmbH, which since 1998 has operated under the title of SL Rasch GmbH Special and Lightweight Structures.
An interdisciplinary team of professionals composed of architects, structural, mechanical and aeronautical engineers, physicists, philosophers and computer specialists, together with departments for  Islamic design, 3D visualization, graphic design and model making works together under one umbrella.
SL Rasch pursues Frei Otto's principles of lightweight construction on the basis of scientific research and brings the minimalistic forms together in harmony with the ornamentation of sacred buildings.The firm works with a High Performance Computing Cluster and develops specific software for different problem solutions.


== Projects (selected) ==
1981: Mountain tents for Muna Valley, Saudi Arabia. With Sami Angawi and Frei Otto
1985: Scientific studies "Climatic research for convertible roofs in Saudi Arabia"
1986: Scientific studies "Simulation and analysis of crowd movement during pilgrimage in the Holy Mosques in Saudi Arabia"
1987: Prototypes for 5×5m solar-powered umbrellas
1987: Toldo for the Quba Mosque in Medina, Saudi Arabia
1988: Convertible roof for the open-air theater in Wiltz, Luxembourg
1990: Tent structures for "Thuwal Palace" beach residence on the Red Sea, Saudi Arabia
1991: 27 sliding domes for the courtyards of the Prophet's Holy Mosque in Medina, Saudi Arabia
1992: 12 large convertible umbrellas (17×18m) in the two large courts of the Prophet's Holy Mosque in Medina, Saudi Arabia
1992: Integrated lighting system for the Piazza of the Prophet's Holy Mosque in Medina, Saudi Arabia
1994: Convertible umbrellas for the Castle of Wasseralfingen, Germany
1995: Domes for the Guekdepe Mosque, Turkmenistan,
1996: Venice Biennale, Starwave tent and 5×5m umbrellas, Venice, Italy
1996: "Jubilee ship", pneumatic structure for the Academy of Arts, Berlin
1997: Tents for beach palace in Obhur, Saudi Arabia
1998: "Maqam Ibrahim" shrine for the al-Haram Mosque in Mecca, Saudi Arabia
1999: Convertible tent for the Robinson Club Fuerteventura, Spain
1999: Domes and lighting system for "Majid Wilayah Persekutuan", Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia
1999: Domes for Putra Mosque, Putrajaya, Malaysia
1999: Fireproof tents for the Muna Tent City, Saudi Arabia
2000: Round tents for a showroom in Leonberg, Germany
2000: Convertible umbrellas (16m×16m) in front of Al Hussein Mosque, Cairo, Egypt
2000: "Kaaba Stairs" movable stairs for the "Kaaba", al-Haram Shareef Mosque, Mecca, Saudi Arabia
2000: Venezuela Pavilion Expo 2000, Hannover
2001: Tanzbrunnen Cologne, renovation of the tent membrane
2001: "Sail Island" sail structures on the Red Sea, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
2001: Stair-climbing ATV
2002: Toldo, Villa d'Este, Rome, Italy
2002: Convertible umbrellas, Hotel d´Angleterre, Lausanne, Switzerland
2002: "Minbar", movable minbar for al-Haram Shareef Mosque, Mecca, Saudi Arabia
2004: Convertible roof for castle ruins, Scherenburg, Germany
2004: Khourais Road Retail Center, roof tent structure Riyadh, Saudi Arabia
2004: Umbrella for the "Stuttgarter Schlossplatz", design with Frei Otto
2004: Vip-Travellounge
2005: Desert Ship 2, Wüstenfahrzeug
2007: Tent structures and lighting system, Royal Terminal, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia.
2007: Convertible umbrellas, Sandy Lane Hotel, Barbados
2008: Convertible umbrellas (29×29m) Royal Terminal, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
2009–2012 Tower tents on the Abraj Al Bait Towers, Makkah, Saudi Arabia
2011: 250 convertible umbrellas (26×26m) for the Prophet's Holy Mosque in Medina, Saudi Arabia
2012: "Royal Clock Tower", clock and tower-top of the Abraj Al Bait Towers, Mecca, Saudi Arabia


== Awards ==
1992: Deutscher Werkbund Bayern (German Work Federation Bavaria)
1993: Best Innovation, "International Association for Automation and Robotics in Construction", Houston, Texas
1993: "Imam Bukhari Educational Complex", Samarkand, Uzbekistan, 1st prize in international competition

text.wiki:
List of works by Antoine Bourdelle is an incomplete list of artworks by the French artist Antoine Bourdelle.
Antoine Bourdelle (31 October 1861 – 1 October 1929), born Émile Antoine Bordelles, was an influential and prolific French sculptor, painter, and teacher. His studio became the Musée Bourdelle, an art museum dedicated to his work, located at 18, rue Antoine Bourdelle, in the 15th arrondissement of Paris, France.
In 1905, he mounted an exhibition of his work at the Galerie Hébrard in Paris, showing 38 sculptures, 18 paintings and 21 drawings. The sculptures included La Nonne from 1888 as well as the Head of Apollo and his Great Tragic Mask of Beethoven. Bourdelle's father died in 1906 and in 1909 he left Rodin's studio. The year 1910, saw his Héraklès tue les oiseaux du lac Stymphale of 1909 shown at the Salon and this was a huge success!  A version of this work is held in the Musée d'Orsay. Whilst working as a sculptor he also taught at the Académie de la Grande Chaumière in Montparnasse, his pupils including Alberto Giacometti, Aristide Maillol, René Iché and Germaine Richier. 1910 also saw his divorce from Stéphanie Van Parys and in 1911 Rhodia Bourdelle was born to him and Cléopâtre Sévastos. In 1913 an exhibition of modern art in New York included his Héraklès and Tête d’Apollon, the commission for the monument to Genéral Alvéar in Argentina was formalized and he carried out the sculptures for the Théâtre des Champs-Elysées. He founded and was vice president of the Salon des Tuileries.Many works by Bourdelle can be seen in the Musée Bourdelle- Buste de Beethoven, Adam, Le bélier rétif, Centaure mourant, La Liberté and Vierge à l'enfant. From 1922 to 1923 he worked on La Vierge à l’offrande and completed the maquette for La France. He also completed La Naissance d’Aphrodite for the Marseille Opera House. In 1925 he exhibited at the Exposition internationale des Arts décoratifs showing Sappho, Le Livre and Masque de Bourdelle in the Pavillon du livre.  1926 finally saw his Alvéar monument inaugurated after 10 years of work and a version of La France was exhibited at the Salon des Tuileries. 1928 saw a retrospective exhibition to celebrate the inauguration of the Brussels Palais des Beaux-Arts and 1929, the year of his death, saw the Monument to Adam Mickiewicz inaugurated. Bourdelle died on the 1 October 1929 at Vésinet whilst a guest of the founder Rudier. In 1931 there was a great retrospective of Bourdelle's work at the Paris Orangerie.  He is buried in Montparnasse cemetery. In 1924 he had been made Commandeur de l'Ordre de la Légion d'honneur.


== War memorials ==
Apart from the war memorials mentioned above Bourdelle also worked on a "Monument aux Députés morts pour La France", a memorial honouring the Deputies who had died in the 1914–18 war. He was keen on placing the memorial in the central niche of the Salle du Roi in the Palais Bourbon, a room dominated by Delacroix' paintings and designed the memorial so as not to clash with these works. The female figure in the statue, said to be based on Isadora Duncan, held a huge short sword and held aloft a round shell of the type carried by Greek hoplites. The piece was called "La Victoir du Droit". Bourdelle completed the maquette, the intention being that the final marble statue would be 3.25m high. Sadly the project was not pursued by the French State.
Bourdelle's 1922/23 La Vierge à l'Offrande or Vierge à l'Enfant in grey chauvigny limestone at Niederbruck, although not an actual war memorial, was directly linked to the 1914–18 war. Léon Vogt, a pupil of Bourdelle, owned potash mines in Alsace and in 1914 his mother vowed that if the family property was kept from destruction during the war she would commission a statue to celebrate this. She died during the war but after the war, Léon commissioned Bourdelle to execute a suitable statue. Bourdelle completed various studies and the second study, enlarged to 2.5m, was placed in the crypt at Hartmannswillerkopf. The same study but now 6m high was placed on the slope of the wooded hill above Niederbruck in the Manavaux valley to fulfil Mme Voigt's vow. The work was exhibited in the "Section d'Art Religieux" at the Salon d'Automne" of 1921–22. In Bourdelle's work the baby Jesus is held above her shoulder by the Virgin Mary, His arms are outstretched so his body takes on the form of a Cross. The inscription on the statue also gives thanks for Alsace-Lorraine's return to France after the war. "En reconnaissance de la protection divine sur la vallée de Masevaux et du retour de l’Alsace-Lorraine à la France les époux Joseph Vogt 1914–1918"


== Images of Bourdelle's war memorials ==

		
		
		
		
		
		
		


== Busts by Bourdelle ==
Louis Gillet wrote "..no one has made more beautiful busts than those of Koeberle, Anatole France, M. Simu, Auguste Perret and Sir James Fraser"Here are details of some of these busts, including the acclaimed studies of Beethoven which occupied Bourdelle over a long period of time. Bourdelle often submitted portrait busts to the Salons in the hope of attracting commissions.  The bust "Adam" was submitted to the Salon des Artists Français in 1888 and he had submitted his bust of Armand Saintis in 1884, Delard in 1885, the actor "Marais" in 1886 and "La Marquise Silvia de Mari" and "St Merlatti" in 1887.


== Cathedrals and churches ==
In 1916 Bourdelle also created a small votive depicting St Barbe which is held by the Lyon Musée des Beaux-Arts. Bourdelle was asked to create the votive by the family of his brother-in-law, Dr Couchoud, as protection for their son who was away fighting in the artillery. Originally it was placed in the church of St Julien de l'Herm near Lyon before being transferred to the museum. The piece is in polychromed cement. There are copies of the work located in Stockholm, Rome, Bruxelles and Luxembourg.

Lived the building and the surrounding gardens. The interactive exhibits were fun even without children. U would like to come another time and cook in the giant kitchen school.

Not a bad place to visit. Perhaps too much reading is required at times and to be honest I lost a bit of interest in reading everything towards the end. Also some if the interactive displays were not functioning. Finally, it was flipping hot inside. The coffee was good in the

Large elegant building that doesn’t provide much content or excitement for visitors. Many of the interactive exhibits didn’t work properly. Many exhibits geared for children but believe many kids would be impatient with slow technology and lack of fun.

if you have Swiss pass it can be free to entry and if you have children, it will give them some educations about the food contents and human body alimentary ,is good for kids from 5-12 y but some tools are broken, if you are adults should not go there because too boring

An interesting place where food (over time) is explained. There are activities and learning programs all interesting. A great way to enjoy new discoveries and intricacies oof food and out health

Some good stuff here and very well presented but for us oldies not terribly exciting. However, the cafe here serves a brilliant soup and their coffee specialities are great. It is a very relaxing environment and you don’t need an entrance ticket to get in.

This was definitely a more interesting exhibit than the Nest and well worth visiting, especially withthe children to explore how food and nutrition is important - strange from the manufacturer of some distinctly artifical foodstuffs.... The highlight had to be the canteen, which

I’ve never been to a food museum so I was intrigued by Alimentarium. But what a great museum, I absolutely loved it, as did my 7 yo daughter. Across multiple floors, this museum takes a look at food across the centuries including how we make, store and transport food. It also
Museum in a beautiful location. Our time was limited as was the attention from the staff. Worth a visit if you are stuck for something to do but I would not schedule a visit

On the top floor of this museum is alot of interactive things for children and adults. Outside there is a live garden. The museum is on the promenade. This museum has explanations in French, German and English. There were no chefs preparing food when I was there I am not

The museum is an interesting one, mostly for those who doesn't know basic bio-technology. It's good for kids, who understand the language, but could be a bore for tech-savvy individual. Not really a tourist attraction for travellers from far away.

While I was hesitant at first, I went in not knowing what to expect from the 'food museum' and I came out having had the most pleasant of surprises!. The museum is interactive, it really invites you to be curious, to play and discover about nutrition, how certain foods dominated
Went with family. Loads of new and useful about agriculture and food with interactive displays. You can easily spend 2 to 3 hours. Great place to visit with kids.
In today's world there are several news and data about food and nutrition. This place show us facts.. it’s very interactive for kids and adults.

This symbol of Vevey (beside the Charlie Chaplin statue) is situated in front of the Food museum and is connected with one of the past exhibitions in the museum. The fork was so interesting for the tourists and probably also for the residents of Vevey that it remained stuck in

We loved the interactive games and panels, and kids had a blast! Amazingly we were able to spend more than 4 hours there. There's a kids' corner close to the cafe with games, books and colouring activities for the children to wind down a bit and process everything they saw.

If you ever visit the lakefront of Vevey and couldn't decide where to get lunch, Alimentarium is definitely the place to have your lunch. The restaurant is organized as a training facility for all the chef-to-be. For less than CHF 20, you get to enjoy a full course with side

As part of the giant Nestle group's headquarters in Vevey Switzerland, we were expecting something really interesting, telling us the history of manufacturing food and some of the reasons for all those strange ingredients on their packaging. What we got, after expensive

We travelled to Switzerland in May 2017 on our grand circle of all the countries that circle the alps. We were specifically targetting the Alimemtarium and fork of Vevey but our GPS had difficulty locating it. Travelling in Europe we dont have a data plan for the backup phone

Very interesting exhibition ,well presented (in English, French, German), also for children. Gardens outside are planted with vegetables, fruit and herbs. Has a restaurant offering three different menus. Food delicious and beautifully presented. Some tables in a most interesting

Went on boat from montreaux to vevey. The town is quaint with lovely views and scenery. Visited museum which is well worth a visit. Very interesting. The building itself is lovely. There is a nice rsetaurant. Would definatley visit again.

There are three Nestle Museums, but we visited just this one. Located opposite the Charlie Chaplin statue and the large fork just off-shore, it’s about a twenty-minutes’ walk along the lake-front from the Nestle Head Office. The friendly receptionist asked if we’d like to

The museum is small and simple, I dont even understand why they call it "museum", it doesnt really look like one. Anyway, it was nice and I dont regret spending one our of my holydays there. The view from the main window is spectacular

When we visited the museum was scheduled to be closed for a refit. While it was an enjoyable and interesting place to visit as a family group, some of the exhibits seemed a bit tired and grubby/worn. That said, I would be happy to visit again after it's been spruced up.

I recently took one of the Alimentarium's Saturday cooking classes. I found out about their cooking classes by visiting their web site and looking for their offerings. I was the only enrolled person in the class! A new Alimentarium employee joined the class due to space
It is interesting to see this big fork on the lake! I would put the knife next too that so we can enjoy seafoods!
Not much thing to do in Vevey, so after/during the walk by the waterfront it is a nice spot to spend some time with a bonus for the best photo stop of Vevey Bay.

If you have children or grand-children to take care while on holidays, or simply friends who visit you, this could be an excellent place to go. This is very well done, orgnaized, very interesting, educative. The place is just superb, in the old Nestle headquarters, a magnificent
This museum tells about the history of food. I realized that children are ver interested. I was less. The restaurant of the Alimentarium offers a nice meal for a reasonable price. pore
Very interesting and the first food museum in the world! Its placed in a beautiful setting right next to the lake Geneva. Worth a visit!
The history of food presented in bite size pieces , it is also interactive which adds to the experience

The Alimentarium is located along the lakeside in Vevey, where fishermen stand and throw their lines, and children on scooters whiz by or groups amble to see the latest exhibition. Now there is a good restaurant / cafe with places outside under the chestut trees, with 3 'menus
its smaller than you would think but its still a nice visit. the lake right in front of it is an amazing visit and you can have a stroll there after your done

We visited this museum after its renovation. It is an interesting concept that has been created with a lot of interactivity from the visitor. Fortunately the museum was not too full, so we have been able to take out time on the many displays and screens on which the vast
Drove the bus there with 12 kids on board. They loved it and the staff really knew how to take them.

The Alimentarium was the primary reason for my visit to Switzerland and I was not disappointed. Recently renovated in 2016, this high-tech interactive education centre was incredibly comprehensive. From the Food sector, to the Society sector to the Body Sector, the edible garden

Perfect place to take kids on a rainy day for a few hours. The museum teaches you in a fun interactive way about food, digesting, the senses, setting a table etc... You can also do workshops for adults and kids parties. The only downside is unfriendly young staff at the
Nice relaxing visit. A good way to spend an hour. The gardens at the back are gorgouse and all is well presented.
Really cool, interactive museum with Special Features on the tour. It's a great idea when you're in Vevey and fun for the whole Family.

This is not a museum in the sense that an adult does not obtain new knowledge. On the other hand it is interactive and really interesting and funny for kids. Cook workshops available. Enjoy a fresh tarte!
Is not really a food museum but a analogy to food viewed trough Nestle corp. eyes.... So is better to spend your time staring at the like unless you are craving for some different experience.

This is a sign of the landscape in Veve- beautiful. Do not miss. We did not go to the museum. Take Photo with a fork in every angle. Nearby is Charlie Chaplin's statue. On Saturday's ther is a nice and colorful market nearby.
This BIG Fork is absolutely the landmark in Vevey, everyone can have so much fun to take many photos in different angles of the fork here.

There has been an impressive job on interactivity wit lots of content available on the numerous screens. This means two things: - You will need time and opportunity to spend lots of time on the screens, which is not so easy if the museum is crowded. You may end up zapping a lot

This museum is a Nestlé sponsored museum and is all about food, food history, where food comes from and anything related to food and cooking. Kids love it. I was personally a bit disappointed. They just reopened after rebuilding the exposition and they could have been a lot more
Did not have time to visit the museum but had a blast taking some snaps with the Fork. Nice piece of innovative art.

I visited the museum with a group of friends. Some of the exhibits are interesting, however, the quality is not unified. It might fit a group of kids, however, I suspect adults will not find is suitable.

The museum was not open when we visited last April but we did not miss the chance to take our picture with THE FORK! What a fun installment! We had some time to wait for our lunch and so we sat lakeside and watched people sit on the chairs that are installed on the rocks and

It didn't cost anything and we had a blast taking picture after picture of us and the folk doing crazy things. Met a family from Morroco who were doing likewise. So we took pictures of them, and they us. Nice cultural exchange.
It's an interesting building with a great garden and cafe right on the lake front. It's interactive. Right outside is a huge fork in the lake marking the "spot".

Museum presents food in all its aspects, not only as a culinary delight. It is interactive, with lot of touch screens and learning games. Very informative and fun, personally, I liked best the part that describes how our body processes food and how our senses react to food.

The Alimentarium re-opened in June 2016 after almost a year of renovations and is now a far more interesting and inter-active place to visit. It is also very "high tech" in that there are loads of touch screens, wall screens etc that explain everything to do with food. (Food
For over 30 years already , the Alimentarium has been sharing a global and independent view of the many aspects of the human diet. Workshops for children & adults !
In the lake, the Fork is there outstanding. You can take a break in front of it. Very pretty lake and small town. You will love it.
Well laid out and very interactive for all ages. If interested in food this is a museum for you. I was disappointed but then not that interested in food.

We were just passing by this lovely building on the promenade in Vevey and thought we would have a look inside! Another fun, well presented Swiss museum, this one all about food. Very interactive and once again, we learned a lot about food! Our 13-year old was thoroughly
It is nice place to visit for everybody. Fresh air, giant lake with high mountains and cloud around. You should go there at the weekend and relax to refresh your mind!
We came upon this sculpture while walking along the waterfront in Vevey. It is a short walk away from the Charlie Chaplin statue.

If you happen to be walking around the old part of Vevey and the lake promenade, then this remarkable newly renovated building is worth a visit. It’s all about food from the beginning of mankind to present junk food and eating habits. Should be very interesting to children and
Even it can be difficult to imagine a musem based on food, this museum worth a visit. Kids have lots of interactive spaces where to learn about food and health.

Lunch and business meeting at the Alimentarium. There is only one menu choice in the restaurant which was packed with healthy vegetables, but a little spicy. Most of the adults were happy with the dish but none of the children found it appealing or appetising - they had to

My children & family have been coming to the Alimentarium for 5 years now and it has always been one of their favourite museums in the area. In fact, most vacations my son insists on visiting it 4 or 5 times. Last year it was closed for renovations, and we were very much
very nice.. very interesting and informative the food museum itself okay and quite a lot of new things you'll never guess from your daily food

A funny mixture of nutritional science and entertainment. There are also interactive expositions where one need to move some objects that can be also fun for little kids, we also liked presentation about tees which took place in a very nice hall. Next visit is planned for there

You will not miss a Big Fork of 26 foot (8 meter), located opposite the Musee de l’Alimentation museum as you walk along the lake in Vevey. Its is just a few meters from the Chaplin statue as well. The fork is an installation to mark the 10th anniversary of the museum and is

We went on the re-opening weekend in June. Overall, the experience was good, and you could probably finish in a couple of hours. If you have kids, the junior academy in the lower level looks like fun. We didn't have enough time to take our kids there unfortunately. The

As a symbol of the Alimentarium Food Museum and regarding food culture this is a really interesting monument which is surrounded by the extremely beautiful mountains and the lake Leman. Also could be made a reference to the monument of Charles Chaplin which is next to this one.

I had been here a year before. It now looked so different and new. This is a Nestle Company facility, extremely well decorated, and different very unique exhibitions. There are amazing lessons in nutrition , a commercial restaurant , and a beautiful kitchen garden with different

This fork is a work of art to mark an anniversary of some kind of the vevey food museum. I was told this controversial piece was removed by the town council and then placed back. Now its an icon of Vevey. I feel it adds to beauty of the lake and very different indeed.
have time on your hand as thereare so many interactivities that you could easily devote half a day. Must try the food served in the cafe! The only meal available then is vegetarian pasta.
Beautiful walk by the lake with lots to look at! One of the most iconic symbols of Vevey. Many tourists love this attraction!
Good museum. If you are a museum lover then you should be here. It's not a must but kind of nice to visit if you are at Vevey.

This is the museum where nestle is explaining all about food... History and associated topical located right on the lake front! The museum also offers theme specific exhibitions that change from time to time.
Many interesting facts around food and human interactions with scents and tastes. Was a great sensorial adventure for kids and adults. Highly recommended.
Is so great visit this museum cause u will see how our meals are evaluated from mny years.... U can also learn cooking and take a tea in the museum. is wonderful for adults and kids.
Fantastic location with great view over lac Leman. Good for family visits. Great temporary exhibitions. Regular cooking master classes for kids and adults-available in either French or English.

You must read reviews carefully, as the museum is getting a major facelift and is closed for 9 months until June 2016. If you look at reviews of this museum, be sure to check the date they VISITED, not when they reviewed the museum. Otherwise you might think that it is open

Good rainy day option. A balance of information, education and fun. Exhibitions changes from time to times. Food is available inside of the museum or the bistros around it. The only museum big enough to be a reason to get out of bed in rainy day within the region.
A unique food museum with interesting interactive exhibits. If you can speak French, there is a cooking class that you can sign up.
Should see this museum if you are visiting VEVEY, Every thing is clear and in detailed to help every one to understand how they produce their products.

The museum is fascinating, and the food workshop are well done, and you get to take what you prepared home! How cool is that! After the visit you have to go to visit the city of Vevey, which is beautiful!

If you like food and want to know the back story on cookware, culinary techniques, history of consumption etc... then this place is for you! There are several interactive exhibits to keep kids and less interested parties engaged. They have a café where they have been

I don't think that this establishment deserves to be 2nd place in Tripadvisor for things to do in Vevey. It is expensive at 12 CHF entrance fee. It is very basic and does not live up to the blurb. It's all about Nestle really and they only pay lip service to putting things in
Go there. You will find interesting museum, nice thematic foods and the possibility to cook yourself, under a cook supervision.

A waste of 12chf. It was very uninspiring. And boring. I was expecting more interactivity around food. Food cannot be this boring. Just a lot of nutritional info. Basic info about cooking over history. Stuff that u already know.
Awesome place to visit. I celebrate my daughter birthday party over there. Nice planning and kids enjoyed a lot. Thanks to all staffs.
Interesting, informative, well laid out. An unexpected different kind of museum. Great for kids, interesting for adults.

We have visited this museum several times, initially with our children who enjoyed the interative displays, and more recently by ourselves. We find there is still plenty for us to learn. It is spread over several floors of an old house and one can get lovely lake views from
This place is just a few steps walk from where I staying in May1,2015. It's a must place to come over and took some pictures. Why? Because it's unique :D

This was a very interesting museum with a lot of interesting and fun facts about food history and nutrition. It appeals to a wide age group with something for everyone, A good way to spend a casual afternoon. The gardens were just as interesting as the inside.

In a town not overflowing with tourist attractions, the Food Museum in Vevey is an interesting enough way to spend a few hours. The bottom floor is about food history generally and includes some interesting artifacts. Upstairs it becomes the Nestle museum for a floor, including

We enjoyed very much the visit. The guide was a very nice lady that explained facts about nutrition and stories about food culture. The museum is extremely nice set, and well decorated, in front of the lake.

This restaurant is part of the Alimentarium food museum and is located is a very light Veranda on the back part of the building. Menus are limited but based on thematic so always with some original combinations

It's a fairly large building, divided according to the individual sections. It is very nicely furnished and interactively. We came less than 60 minutes before closing time, because we had no idea how big the museum is. The lady at the ticket office told us that this time is
The little shop downstairs has some really lovely gifts and kitchen ware for sale. The place is light and airy and its great if you have guests visiting as a local attraction
Sight seeing with friends, loved seeing Charlie and the fork. Took a walk down to the castle as well :) a nice trip out !!!!:)

If you have time on your hands and want to be more informed about food, this is a good place to go. Quite varied in the type of exhibits, it has something for people of all ages. Some machines give out chocolates for you to taste :)

I got the feeling that Food is just an excuse to advertise Nestlé company. It was raining and we where with a couple of friends with a son who's 1 year old. As it was lunch time for the baby, we went to the restaurant (self service) of the museum to get 4 drinks and sit on a

There is lots to do. The exhibits are interactive and educational. Four floors of food history and food processing and nutritional education. The gardens outside are amazing. They had artichokes that had gone to bloom.
I was amazed by the size of it It was huge and shiny very amazing I loved the small chairs installed between the rocks it gave me an opportunity to take good photos of me and my family

Very nice museum with many interesting thing, pictures, information and interactive games and tests. Good for adult as well as for children. For example machine gives you some pill and you have to recognise right taste. We spend there over two hours.

There's a changing temporary exhibition and also permanent exhibition, all based on food: history, nutrition, trade, etc. Many aspects of the museum are geared towards children with interactive points and workshops. Many school come her. True, it is run by the local food

The Alimentarium is a museum about all aspects of food as consumption. Simple but convincing exhibits about packaging, changing consumption patterns, food production. One hour workshops in a fully equipped kitchen under the guidance of a real chef. Children until 12 are welcome

A giant stainless steel fork is stuck in the lake. Just behind is the Museum. If you have the Swiss Rail Pass, there's no entrance fee and it's worth a quick look. We had lunch outside on the picnic tables and just sit by the lake and enjoyed the view of the fork with the Swiss

We went here in January 2014 and were very disappointed. You are charged for entrance into what is really a promotion for Nestle products and a very poor one at that. Very boring museum with very little in it and terrible effort on the part of Nestle! At the very least you

The museum was a positive experience, with things to do for both children and adults. The interactive part, where you for example could taste and smell different things, was really nice. And the more educational parts of the exhibition were also interesting and well made.

An interesting visit, interactive, you have the possibilities to make some small test,( like smelling perfumes and guess what smell it is ) some of the special exhibitions are very interesting,but the whole could be more original and surprising...

The education on the benefits of eating well and sticking to the food pyramid are good. It is really geared for children. Some history of food is included. Cafe is open for only an hour and a half--disappointing.

First impressions are so important, and yet the reception at this museum leaves a bad memory as you enter the museum. Employees who can barely take the time to greet you, and who give the impression that they are not happy, and come across as rude. The museum itself is well
Amazing. we had a great time. It's a must see for families VERY EDUCATIONAL some funny games inside. good experience

A giant stainless steel fork is stuck in the lake. You've probably seen photos. Plastic chairs are amusingly placed among the boulders at the lake's shore. Just behind is the Museum. If you have the Swiss Rail Pass, there's no entrance fee and it's worth a quick look. You will

The garden as you enter the museum is fantastic. Many plants all labelled. Tis year the theme was plants in paintings and so next to some of the plants were pairings of the plant or the vegetable it produced. Inside the presentations were in different rooms relating to the
We enjoyed it, kids will love it! The museum is set up interactivlely and there are lots of pull out drawers, quizes and fun things for children to do and for adults to learn from.

This Museum is nice and interesting for kids meanly. All explanation are written in 3 languages, French, German, English It covers many aspects about food, detailed and easy to understand. The exhibition is done very well. It is a special and cute museum, suitable for kids.

The garden surrounding the building and the planters throughout had a wonderful selection of fresh vegetables and herbs. The exhibition on nutrition was interesting and the fresh cakes were really nice.

It was already almost 13 years ago that I was in Vevey, but this time it was the first time I visited this Food Museum. It was quite impressive and good to learn again, although the price was indeed quite high, but it was Switzerland :-)

Visited the Alimentarium last week. Was OK overall with some interesting aspects, but in my opinion it's overpriced at CHF12 per adult. Some interesting elements (test kitchen and veggie/herb garden in front), but many of interactive exhibits were out of order and the whole
What a Museum!!! Makes you think anew about food and its history.Nothing to dislike.Good self interaction with exhibits.Great for kids too.
Cannot miss! Liked : Great for family....great lunches too! Excellent experience and value. A must do. Disliked : none

My husband and I had a very fun time in the alimentarium. Must try the food served in the cafe! The only meal available then is vegetarian pasta. My husband, a meat lover, was disappointed at first but the vegetarian pasta was so good he wanted to have it again for dinner! Too

An interesting and informative attraction. Situated on the lakeside next to the Charley Chaplin statue and the fork sculpted to celebrate 10 years of this Nestlé attraction. The plat du jour menu in the restaurant is of good quality and value.
Great place to go with Kids, and have time on your hand as thereare so many interactivities that you could easily devote half a day!!!

My friends and I started our walk from the Nestle Headquater, along the lake to the fork. It was a very pleasant walk, so I would definitely recommend it to everyone. The fork was very interesting, just outside the food museum. We didn't pay to go in to the food museum, but just

This is an interesting museum with a lot of history of food, but it's getting quite dated. The museum does offer an interactive part that is very good for the kids. I understand they are revamping the entire museum, so perhaps it will be better when they reopen.

The Museum is really interesting, showing many aspects about food, detailed and easy to understand. The building is owned by the Nestlé company and was used at earlier times as their headquarter. Currently still some courses and representative cvents are held by Nestlé. The

We thought that this was a nice museum for all ages. There were some games for everyone. The garden was very nice and had a large choice of vegetables and herbs. There are some cooking workshop proposed for all ages. We really enjoyed it!
Great fun for the kids, the chocolate machine, giant hamster wheel and 3D cinema were cool. Thoroughly enjoyed learning about food and how its changed over the years.
The museum was fine, but nothing too exceptional. I expected more. Was a clean, well organized museum, just not as interesting as I expected.

I'm not a lover of museums...but when interactivity plays with history, this is where you can find me! The Alimentarium is definitely a different "museum (I don't like call it a museum)". A place where you can learn, share and enjoy elements which are linked to our everyday

Went there today. A lot of interesting thing related to food and health. There's a nice small kitchen for kids play. Many games provided related to sensory and 3D movie too. Wifi provided for free. Recommended!

Not often there is a museum based on food. It talks about how the food culture has changed over the years, from eating habits, food consumption etc to the appliances, what the food has done to the body promoting healthy eating. Great place for kids to learn and understand
MUSEUM Alimentarium is just across the Lake Leman. This center has " cuisine" classes for adults and children in certain months of the year.
Go to their website and see if there are any workshops for kids. My 6 yr old at the time did a chocolate egg workshop. He loved it. The museum is fun for kids as well.
Great place to take your kids for a tour. Very good infrastructure and guides. It worth a visit if you are in Vevey.

Fun visit on the beautiful lake side in Vevey. If the weather does not entice you to stay outside and profit from the gorgeous waterfront you can drop by the museum, a nice and informative visit. The cooking classes are fun for kids but I think you have to sign up in advance.

The exhibits were interactive, bright, and colorful. Very relevant. We enjoyed it from cultural, health, and artistic perspectives. They also have a cafeteria where you can lunch on food prepared on-site.

The view from the Lake is wonderful and information about food processing is something we need to refresh and see what we missed out. The food are in teh Cafeteria was amazing, the staff are so delicated to make the food with good value of money. You must try the healthy way

So many fun things at this museum. I like to look at all the old cooking tools. They try to represent food from all around the world, and even have a New York hot dog cart. I was disappointed to see the American diet represented by fast food hamburger, fries and a coke.
Fun for adults and kids. creative displays. You got to test out a little food and see a garden outside of herbs. interactive museum

We visited in September after having gone for a walk along the waterfront. Whilst I can appreciate all the effort that went into the displays, most of the interactive information provided are what I learnt in high school Home-economics, the rest we read about in magazines and

This is not just a museum , but an experience and an education but really fun for all ages and very well worth a visit. Allow about 2 hours.. and why not try to book for a cooking course just a couple of hours.
You learn a lot about food and you can easily spend a few hours in the museum. Good entertainment for kids from around 5 years
A very nice museum which gives you a sense of your body and food. Good for all ages to gain a better understanding of the matter. Worth visiting if you are around!

We've visited here 3 times, each time taking one of their cooking classes. The people here are so friendly, the exhibits are well done and the price is right. Lots of interactive stuff and the cooking classes can't be beat. They are only in French, but we managed to figure out
There are things I did not know about my food, I went there with my grand daughter when she visited me, there were activities especially organized for children

text.wiki:
Lake Geneva (French: lac Léman [lak lemɑ̃] or le Léman [lə lemɑ̃], rarely lac de Genève [lak də ʒ(ə)nɛv]; German: Genfersee [ˈɡɛnfərˌzeː]) is a lake on the north side of the Alps, shared between Switzerland and France. It is one of the largest lakes in Western Europe and the largest on the course of the Rhône. Of it 59.53% (345.31 km2 or 133.32 sq mi) comes under the jurisdiction of Switzerland (cantons of Vaud, Geneva, and Valais), and 40.47% (234.71 km2 or 90.62 sq mi) under France (department of Haute-Savoie).


== Name ==
The first recorded name of the lake is Lacus Lemannus, dating from Roman times; Lemannus comes from Ancient Greek Liménos Límnē (Λιμένος Λίμνη) meaning "port's lake"; it became Lacus Lausonius, although this name was also used for a town or district on the lake, Lacus Losanetes, and then the Lac de Lausanne in the Middle Ages. Following the rise of Geneva it became Lac de Genève (translated into English as Lake of Geneva), but Lac Léman was the common name on all local maps and is the customary name in the French language. In contemporary English, the name Lake Geneva has become predominant.


== Geography ==
Lake Geneva is divided into three parts because of its different types of formation (sedimentation, tectonic folding, glacial erosion):
Haut Lac (Upper Lake), the eastern part from the Rhône estuary to the line of Meillerie–Rivaz
Grand Lac (Large Lake), the largest and deepest basin with the lake's largest width
Petit Lac (Small Lake), the most south-west, narrower and less deep part from Yvoire–Promenthoux next Prangins to the exit in GenevaAccording to the Swiss Federal Office of Topography, Swisstopo, Lac de Genève designates that part of the Petit Lac, which lies within the cantonal borders of Geneva (excluding the cantonal exclave Céligny), so about from Versoix–Hermance to the Rhône outflow in Geneva.

The Chablais Alps border is its southern shore, the western Bernese Alps lie over its eastern side. The high summits of Grand Combin and Mont Blanc are visible from some places. Compagnie Générale de Navigation sur le lac Léman (CGN) operates boats on the lake.
The lake lies on the course of the Rhône. The river has its source at the Rhône Glacier near the Grimsel Pass to the east of the lake and flows down through the canton of Valais, entering the lake between Villeneuve and Le Bouveret, before flowing slowly towards its egress at Geneva. Other tributaries are La Dranse, L'Aubonne, La Morges, La Venoge, La Vuachère, and La Veveyse.

Lake Geneva is the largest body of water in Switzerland, and greatly exceeds in size all others that are connected with the main valleys of the Alps. It is in the shape of a crescent, with the horns pointing south, the northern shore being 95 km (59 mi), the southern shore 72 km (45 mi) in length. The crescent form was more regular in a recent geological period, when the lake extended to Bex, about 18 km (11 mi) south of Villeneuve. The detritus of the Rhône has filled up this portion of the bed of the lake, and it appears that within the historical period the waters extended about 2 km (1.2 mi) beyond the present eastern margin of the lake. The greatest depth of the lake, in the broad portion between Évian-les-Bains and Lausanne, where it is just 13 km (8.1 mi) in width, has been measured as 310 m (1,020 ft), putting the bottom of the lake at 62 m (203 ft) above sea level. The lake's surface is the lowest point of the cantons of Valais and Vaud. The culminating point of the lake's drainage basin is Monte Rosa at 4,634 metres above sea level.

The beauty of the shores of the lake and of the sites of many of the places near its banks has long been celebrated. However, it is only from the eastern end of the lake, between Vevey and Villeneuve, that the scenery assumes an Alpine character. On the south side the mountains of Savoy and Valais are for the most part rugged and sombre, while those of the northern shore fall in gentle vine-covered slopes, thickly set with villages and castles.The snowy peaks of the Mont Blanc are shut out from the western end of the lake by the Voirons mountain, and from its eastern end by the bolder summits of the Grammont, Cornettes de Bise and Dent d'Oche, but are seen from Geneva, and between Nyon and Morges. From Vevey to Bex, where the lake originally extended, the shores are enclosed by comparatively high and bold mountains, and the vista terminates in the grand portal of the defile of St. Maurice, cleft to a depth of nearly 2,700 m (8,900 ft) between the opposite peaks of the Dents du Midi and the Dent de Morcles.The shore between Nyon and Lausanne is called La Côte because it is flatter. Between Lausanne and Vevey it is called Lavaux and is famous for its hilly vineyards.The average surface elevation of 372 m (1,220 ft) above sea level is controlled by the Seujet Dam in Geneva.


== Climate ==
Due to climate change, the average temperature of deep water (more than 300 metres or 980 feet deep) increased from 4.4 °C (39.9 °F) in 1963 to 5.5 °C (41.9 °F) in 2016 (an increase of 1.1 °C or 2.0 °F in 53 years), while the average temperature of surface water (five metres or 16 feet deep) increased from 10.9 °C (51.6 °F) in 1970 to 12.9 °C (55.2 °F) in 2016 (up 2 °C or 3.6 °F in 46 years).


=== Bise ===
Lake Geneva (and particularly the lakeside parts of the city of Geneva) can be affected by the cold Bise, a northeasterly wind. This can lead to severe icing in winter. The strength of the Bise wind can be determined by the difference in air pressure between Geneva and Güttingen in canton of Thurgau. The Bise arises when the air pressure in Güttingen is higher than in Geneva.


== Environment ==

In 563, according to the writings of Gregory of Tours and Marius Aventicensis, a tsunami wave swept along the lake, destroying the fort of Tauredunum and other settlements, and causing numerous deaths in Geneva. Simulations indicate that the Tauredunum event was most likely caused by a massive landslide near the Rhône delta, which caused a wave eight metres (26 ft) high to reach  within 70 minutes. In 888 the town was part of the new Kingdom of Burgundy, and, with it, was absorbed into the Holy Roman Empire in 1033.
In the late 1960s, pollution made it dangerous to swim at some beaches of the lake; indeed, visibility under water was near zero. By the 1980s, intense environmental pollution (eutrophication) had almost wiped out all the fish. Today, pollution levels have been dramatically cut back, and it is again considered safe to swim in the lake. Major leisure activities practiced include sailing, wind surfing, boating (including water skiing and wake-boarding), rowing, scuba diving and bathing.
A total of four submarines have plied the depths of Lake Geneva.
In 1964, Jacques Piccard launched a tourist-oriented submarine, the Auguste Piccard (named for his explorer father), for the Swiss National Exhibition, meant to honor the Expo 64 theme of accomplishments by Swiss engineers and industry. After operating through to 1965 in Lake Geneva, Piccard used the vessel for scientific exploration in other parts of the world. Piccard later built the F.-A. Forel, launched in Lake Geneva in 1978 and used primarily for scientific research until it was retired in 2005. In 2011, in a collaborative operation led by École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, two Mir submersibles were used for ten weeks to conduct extensive scientific research in Lake Geneva.On a scientific footnote, in 1827, Lake Geneva was the site for the first measurement of the speed of sound in (fresh) water.  French mathematician Jacques Charles François Sturm and Swiss physicist Daniel Collodon used two moored boats, separated by a measured distance, as the transmit and receive platforms for the sounds of exploding gunpowder.  The loud airborne sound coupled into the lake, establishing a loud underwater sound that could be measured at a distance.  The flash of the exploding gunpowder provided the visual starting cue for the timepiece, and the underwater explosion sound striking a bell provided the finish cue.
The lake is rich in wildlife, especially birds: both the common buzzard and the red kite  breed  here in considerable numbers.


== Sport events ==
Yacht racing is a popular sport, and high-performance catamarans have been developed specifically for the lake.  The design of the Alinghi 5, the defender of the 2010 America's Cup, was influenced by those racing catamarans.  The best-known event, the "Bol d'Or" (not to be confused with other events having the same name) runs from Geneva to the end of the lake and back.The Tour du Lac rowing event also takes place on Lake Geneva. Competitors row once around the entire lake, making this 160-kilometre (99 mi) event the longest non-stop rowing regatta in the world.
Several competitions for swimmers are organised yearly like the crossing of the lake from Lausanne to Evian (13km), from Chillon Castle to Geneva (70km),  from Montreux to Clarens (1.8 km), in Geneva (1.8 km), all in summer, and the Coupe de Noël, 125m in Geneva in December.


== Towns and villages ==


== Notable residents ==
Edmund Ludlow, famous as one who had signed the death warrant of English King Charles I, was granted on 16 April 1662 protection in and continued to live at Vevey until his death in 1692.Mary and Percy Shelley and Lord Byron holidayed by the lake and wrote ghost stories, one of which became the basis for the novel Frankenstein. The Empress Elisabeth of Austria (Sisi) was stabbed to death on the quayside in Geneva in September 1898. Vladimir Lenin rented a little "chalet" at the French bank, near Geneva. Actor Charlie Chaplin spent his final years and died in Vevey (there is a memorial statue of him along the promenade; his home at Corsier-sur-Vevey is now a museum of his life and career). Actors Noël Coward, James Mason, Sir Peter Ustinov, Richard Burton and Audrey Hepburn all lived in villages on the shores of or in view of the lake.  David Bowie moved to a chalet to the north of Lake Geneva in 1976, which inspired him to take up painting and informed the first stages of the "Berlin Trilogy". Pop singer Phil Collins lives in a home overlooking the lake.  Rock band Queen owned and operated Mountain Recording Studios (which is still in use today) in Montreux, and a statue of lead singer Freddie Mercury, who also owned a second home in Montreux, stands on the northern shore of the lake. Writer Vladimir Nabokov also took residence in Montreux, where he died in 1977. Ex-Formula 1 driver Michael Schumacher lives with his family in a home overlooking the lake.


== See also ==
Lake Geneva region


== References ==


== External links ==
Lake Geneva Region
International Commission for the Protection of Lake Geneva (CIPEL)
Lake Geneva in  German, French and Italian in the online Historical Dictionary of Switzerland.

If you're a Queen/Freddie fan, this is a MUST to come and see. The views over the lake are outstanding, sunsets are breathtaking! Leave a momento or look and read what others have left (I did 😊) Fantastic photo opportunities and situated right in the market square!
The statue is located along the lakeside walk. It’s a nice tribute. Many people leave flowers. Take a stroll and snap a photo. Nearby is the casino, shopping and dining.

Giving this a 5-star rating because it’s a nice piece of art that’s easily accessible for free. And if you happen to be a Queen fan, you’ve got to check this box. It’s part of the Lakeside Promenade, which is a must-do activity when visiting Montreux.

This statue of Freddie Mercury is in a lovely spot in Montreux overlooking the lake - but get up early if you want him to yourself! Despite the rain, when we visited there were a lot of other people clambering around the statue and having their photograph taken with him which is
If you’re a fan and in the Lake Geneva area, it’s worth a stop in Montreaux for lunch and a photo with Freddie!

The stunning sea front walk along the banks of lake Geneva in Montreux, Switzerland will ensure you stumble across this great statue of the late king of rock! It’s situated close to lots of bars, cafes and hotels. Well worth a visit if your traveling to the area and if you can
Overlooking lac leman, this statue of Freddy is a great likeness and in a good spot not to be missed.

Wonderful statue of Freddy. A must for any queen fan or general rock music fan. I would rate this statue to the same level as the imagine gardens in NYC. Go when it’s lunch time, less people about to get a nice photo!

If you are a Queen fan, then this statue of Freddy Mercury should be on your must see list on a visit to Montreux. Also close by is a kinetic sculpture in an old phone booth. All for free as you walk along the lake path in Montreux.
You can't miss this statue if you are walking along the lakefront, and especially if you are a queen fan! I didn't make it to the museum but Montreux is a beautiful city.
Best City I visit so far in Switzerland. It was Christmas time and streets and the market was really nice.

On a recent visit to Montreux we saw the Freddie Mercury memorial which is a lifeli8ke statue of Freddie Mercury but unfortunately we did not have the time to see the Queen experience exhibition due to lack of time.
Not well maintained. Very shabby deadTributes left behind. Spoils it completely. I'm not sure how often it is cleaned up but it is not enough

a British singer-songwriter and record producer, best known as the lead vocalist of the rock band Queen. Mercury died in 1991 at age 45 due to complications from AIDS,  Why his statue built here? In 1978, the singer came to the Montreux Jazz Festival to record the album “Jazz”
Very thoughtful and nice sculpture of Freddie overlooking the lake and the mountains. So beautiful! A

Who can't stop to see Freddie, one of the greatest singer and musicians ever. We loved you Freddie. At least Adam Lambert can sing and perform some of your songs to keep you alive. Love of my life. Beautiful
From Zanzibar to Montreux. We are huge fans of this iconic star and visit the site every time we visit. Pls never remove this musical legend from this beautiful place.

A must do option to do in Montreux! Very nice place and memories of Queen close to the city center and Christmas market.
Great memories and nice memorial. Typical of Montreux. Very nice to see. At the Christmas market. Beautiful.

As well as the statue of Freddy, there are many others along the shoreline. Some I knew, such as Charlie Chaplin, others I did not, but there were plaques on each

Saw the statue earlier today whilst visiting the Christmas Market. Great lakeside location, lots of tourists snapping photos and some flowers left in tribute.

A really nice tribute to the king (queen?) of rock. it's quite impressive to see how many flowers bouquets are left there by fans, even after all this time. Any day you go there will be something left to him by someone. It's best enjoyed in a sunny summer day, after a walk

The Freddie Mercury statue was located right by Lake Geneva. It's a nice addition to this town and sits in the middle of the Xmas market. There is also a Queen studio nearby.

Wouldn't go here especially to see this, however it is a nice statue, good likeness. The walk along lake Geneva however is lovely, beautiful and floral, many good photo opportunities, and take a trip on the boat too, and a trip on the cog railway up to Roychers de Naye.
It is great that Montreux has honoured Freddy Mercury with such a great statue. Certainly a surreal setting during the afternoon sunset! Don't miss it is you are in Montreux.
it would be a nice experience for queen's fan, Beautiful Lakeside scenery , beautiful statue, it was so great. if you have chance to be in Montreux, then go for it ...
Well represented statue of Freddie Mercury. It's located in a nice part of the city, in front of the lake. It's a must of Montreux!

...Freddie Mercury celebration, so we enjoyed the extra music and excitement on the Promenade. I couldn't remember who he was but the fans quickly reminded me, Queen! He had property here and now has a statue right on the water.

This was a surprise as we walked along the promenade. The bronze of Freddy Mercury is captivating. I learned that this icon spent many years in Montreal and died there.
Good place for evening walk beside the lake geneva surrounded by beautiful mountains.LOVE THIS PLACE !!
For the music enthusiasts, this is a must-see statue of Freddie Mercury along the lake. It is bigger than normal.

Many stand and mimic the Freddie stance. Few do it well. People watching is an added entertaining bonus to this celebrated statue figure of Freddie Mercury. Be sure to read the plaque to appreciate his links with Montreux.
On the front looking out on Lac Leman . Have your photo taken by it if it’s not too busy! Not much more to say about it really

This is a must see when in Montreux. Pretty well patronised as well. Well located just beside the lake and the marche. Also on the promenade thats tracks along the lake front from Clarens to Chillon (and probably further)

we were walking near the vank & suddenly i saw this statue where some old people were taking selfies or pics. then my friend noticed me about it “the Freddie Mercury statue”. you can reach here by walk if you come by train station or by bus. the is situated near the bank.a opean

lively place with wonderful gurgling water fountains and photo spots. you will find numerous artists painting and playing music near this place. a bit touristy but very clean and serene. its like a pilgrimage for queen fans

It's there so.... When you are walking along the lake in Montreux it's hard to miss The statue of Freddy Mercury who spent his final years in Montreux. A very popular attraction.

The monument was larger than expected, but in scale with its surroundings. Wonderful and well executed, the statue of Freddie Mercury is a nice start or finish to a walk in the beautiful promenade that goes on for miles to the Chateau de Chillon and beyond.

A tribute from Montreux city to the leader of the Queen musical band. He fell in love with that city where he found peace and serenity after he became ADS sick. The statue was created by a Czech sculptor and dedicated to Mercury as a ‘lover of life, singer of songs’.
Walked here from our hotel for a sun downer. Lovely place to chill at the promenade. Being fans of Freddy Mercury, it was nostalgic.
Not much here, just an average statute. It said there were flowers on it at all times, we didnt see any.
Didnt expect to see this on the lakeside, but it is a good likeness. Lots of people taking selfies with him.
Sure it’s there and there are wonderful things around it. Just take your photo and go do other things.

The iconic Freddie statue on the shore of Lake Geneva is a must visit for anyone who has an interest in Queen. There is also the Queen studio experience in the Montreux casino nearby which is free to enter.
i guess plan to be there in early morning, before tour groups hit the memorial; path along lake was under construction- so this made seeing the memorial difficult, too
A must see if you are staying in the area. Interesting area surrounding the statue that you should check out and there are lots of dinning options around.

We went to Montreux to see Freddie's statue and the Queen studios, we were lucky and the weather was hot, we got loads of photos with the memorial we were not disappointed, it is situated next to the lake and it was just around the corner from our hotel

The lakeside walk at Montreux is beautiful and should not be missed. Along the walk you cannot miss the Freddie Mercury statue. It is in a prime location next to the covered market.
The Freddie Mercury Memorial is a beautiful tribute to a larger than life performer. He faces the lake and is beautiful (all times but especially) at sunset.
As well as a visit to the Queen Studio Experience this is a must for any Freddie Mercury/Queen fans. Lovely location and a great photo opportunity.

Yeah it's a statue of Freddie Mercury. It looks like him. I enjoyed seeing it on my way to the mall.
Great studio museum. Mesmerized even the non fan. For the fans, this is a must do halt when in Montreaux. Located within the casino premises.

You're just walking along and there he is, larger than life. A bit of a line up, but everyone wants their picture posing with Freddie.

This rock legend is a must go if you are in Montreux ! There is nearby a place to swim in the lake !

freddies statue is on the banks of lake geneva in the gorgous montreaux. very popular for photo oppoprtunity,

Anyone who loves music will love this, Perfect way to remember Freddie in his classic pose. It feels ever minute of every day someone is taking a photo. Long may it overlook the lake. Must see if in the area,
The statue is a must see in Montreux. Just a short pilgrimage type visit is needed. The attraction is that it is brilliantly maintained and permanently being photoed / selfied.
